We stayed 3nights in the Premiere Suite.Pros:1) nice beautiful room - modern n clean2) perfect location - took airport limo bus to cerulean tower Tokyo hotel in shibuya (3100yen/pax, took abt 1hr) & walked about 5mins to granbell Shibuya - walk about 5mjns to shibuya train station through the bridge or main strip /junction for food and shopping- there's 7/11 and family Mart less than 3mins walk from hotel3) great jap breakfast on 2nd floor (have choice of jap or continental set)4) nice bath tub in room5) free wi-fiCons:1) the premier suite was too dark for our liking but it was the last room left (38,000yen/night, total 114,000yen for 3Ns including breakfast for 2) during peak season of cherry blossom in Shibuya2) premier suite is a loft with a spiral staircase - not suitable for people having that problem and obvioisly very inconvenient to bring up large luggags- we left our luggage at the foot of stairs and only brought our cabin bag up3) optional Buffett breakfast avail at 1st story Restaurent name cono- worst experience cover in Japan!!! On our last day, we thought to try something different, moment we walked in, before we could see the spread for the Buffett (which was quite limited) a plum guy behind the counter asked for our breakfast coupon and said please bring your tray back.There were no plates left at the Buffett table, we had to ask for them - and the guy had this huge attitude of "don't bother me" and put a huge stack of wet plates at the Buffett table didn't even bother drying themFood was cold - sausages and eggs espWe waited for another lady to come behind the counter and then asked if they had paper napkins or serviettes. She said no. So I pointed to the plates and said but the plates are wet. Then she spoke in Japanese to the guy, pulled out some towel which j hope is clean!!! N dried 2plates for us.Unbelievable!!! For almost $400/night this type of service and shockingly worst service of Japan we have ever received - we been to Japan more than 20times and this trip was so last minute that the hilton shinjuku and Conrad and ritz Carlton and cereluan tower shibuya were all fully booked that's why we thought we'll try this hotel for its central location.

Good hotel, friendly staff, close to station, plenty of great restaurants and bars close at hand. Don't expect a big room, this Toyko!Breakfast was great, nice bar for a late night drink. Washing machine and dryer for guests.

We are a family of 4, 2 adults and 2 teenagers. We stayed there in 2013, 2014 and 2015.The hotel is well located, very near to many restaurantes ( Japanese, Korean BBQ, Tapas, Italian...). Two options of breakfast in two different restaurants. Excellent internet wifi connection. We took 2 Premiere double room, comfortable size (Its Japan after all). We are already planning a trip to Japan in the future and will definitely stay there again!

We stayed here for a few nights at the end of our trip to Japan. It is 5min walk from Shibuya station – so is very convenient for getting around and exploring western Tokyo.We were there on honeymoon – and the hotel manager (who is a really nice chatty/smiley guy) upgraded us to a suite on the 8th floor. The suite is set over two floors – a small lounge area downstairs with TV and coffee machine; and the bedroom and bathroom (includes an onsen-like bath as well as a shower) upstairs. Large and comfortable bed, free in room wifi, and also stereo etc (although made for old-style ipod, so couldn’t connect newer iphones).That said, the room was in need of a little sprucing up (e.g. there was a cigarette burn in the sofa; marks on the wall; a couple of stains on the carpet). And the upstairs level was very warm despite our best efforts to use the aircon (leaving it on at the lowest temperature). The hotel offers either Japanese or continental breakfast – we only tried the latter, which I would not recommend. We came down admittedly at the end of the service, but the options (cold scrambled eggs and sausages; a bit of salad; and a basket of bread) were really not inspiring. I would just suggest the hotel stop offering this actually – especially given there are lots of cafes around the hotel it doesn’t need to offer this. Overall, it was a decent hotel – but with a few changes and a spruce up they could really move this up the market.

The room was extremely clean. It wasn't as small as I thought it was going to be - there was plenty of room. Breakfast was included which wasn't a great sized portion (you had to choose from a menu, no buffet) but lots of tea, coffee and fresh orange juice. The reception staff were helpful in giving directions and recommendations. It's very close to the train station so perfect if you need to catch an early train to the airport in the morning. I would stay here again.

Nice location, 5minutes walking from shibuya station (west exit), nice and very helpfull staff. Small and Simple modern room. Close to drOp point of airport limosine bus,reservation needed for airport limosine, direct train to narita airportfrom shibuya stasion

Very nice, modern hotel that's very close to the Shibuya train station, making it really easy to get there from the airport. The only thing is that the station is huge, so although you're really close to the hotel it can take a long while (took me more than a half hour!) to figure out which exit to go out of and to find your way to the hotel. There are directions on the site, but they took a while to understand. You may want to mark the location on a map. I had breakfast included, but it was a rather small breakfast and it was really strange that the restaurant where breakfast takes place doesn't have access to the WiFi in the rest of the hotel.

Great location from Haneda airport (easy to find 10 minute walk from the Cerulean tower hotel by airport limousine). Also quick walk to Shibuya subway station, to Shibuya crossing and nearby lots of restaurants. Tons of shopping also within a short distance of the hotel. We walked to Harajuku area and that was less than a 30 minute walk away. Again more shopping and restaurants. Great breakfast every morning. Certainly good variety and quality for a continental from eggs to soup to sit down if you chose the other option. We tried both sit down and buffet and preferred the first floor buffet. Perfectly designed room to maximize space. Full bath and amazing shower. High water pressure and have to admit we loved the fancy toilet seats. Comfy bed and duvet. Great sleep and also for tossing and turning due to Jetlag!Happy with our choice as hotels can be quite pricey in Tokyo.

Although the room was a little small, it is well located to the main hub of Shibuya and train lines (JR aswell as metro). It was very clean and well presented, staff were friendly and helpful. We did find it a little difficult to locate but that was due to our own navigational skills after a long flight, however a lovely Japanese girl helped us find our way

The Shibuya Granbell is a small hotel located about 3 minutes from the Shibuya Metro and JR stations. If you're trying to figure out where in Tokyo to stay, Shibuya is always my choice. You can get virtually anywhere from the Shibuya station, so it's a great launching point, and Shibuya has more restaurants, bars, entertainment venues and shopping areas than you could ever explore. The streets are very safe at night; so there is plenty to do nearby, at all hours. The Granbell is over the pedestrian overpass, and then about 2 short blocks, headed away from the noise. So the hotel is extremely quiet. I can't remember ever hearing street noise or noise from the hallway or other rooms. If you're traveling to the hotel from the station with baggage, you will have to go over the pedestrian overpass. Look for the elevator on the corner to get you up to the overpass rather than trying to walk up the stairs or the ramp.The hotel rooms are small, but very reasonably priced. If you're only in the room to sleep, who needs space? You can walk around, even with baggage spread on the floor. The bed is comfortable enough, and the pillows are fine. The bathroom is modern, with a nice rainshower head in the bathtub/shower. One important thing about the rooms are the inadequacy of the lighting. It is not possible to read a book or magazine at night; there are only tiny bed lamps with red shades (which reduce the light) and oddly placed tiny recessed lights in the ceiling. I was able to read on my backlit iPad, but could not read traditional print media or find stuff in my baggage. This really needs to be improved upon. Or you can take a small personal light.There are adequate numbers of electric outlets to charge your stuff, and they are conveniently placed in the desk unit.The backroom products are plentiful and good quality: shower gel, shampoo, conditioner, shavers, toothbrushes, combs, all replenished every day. One black eye for our cleaning team -- they let us completely run out of toilet paper, and we had to trek down to reception to get a roll. That should NEVER happen.Breakfast has two options. On the first floor is minimalist -- corn flakes is about all I saw, but it's in the bar, and smokers are all around you. So we never chose that option. On the second floor is the dining room. The menu options there were the same 3 every day: (1) traditional Japanese breakfast, which we never tried, but it contained some fish, noodles, and some other stuff; (2) scrambled eggs and bacon and salad with 2 tiny chunks of pineapple; or (3) 2 small pieces of french toast, bacon and salad with the same 2 tiny chunks of pineapple. The absence of variety got very old after a couple days. The bacon is virtually uncooked; so we couldn't eat it. The french toast is thick and undercooked. We ate the breakfast for 3 days and then skipped it for the rest of the stay because it was just too hard to choke down. In general, I don't expect a good breakfast when it's an included (free) option, so I take it in stride when it's not good, but for a hotel that otherwise has its act together, I would suggest that if they're going to offer the breakfast, they should make an effort to improve the quality and variety. Overall, it's a great hotel, and I will stay here again and again, but seriously, I will bring a little personal lantern next time and won't waste my calorie budget on the breakfast.

Convenient location 2 minutes away from the train station, lovely staff that get a special shout out for helping me with a passport drama with clean and tidy rooms.Hotel is definitely all you need for a stay in Tokyo - a comfortable bed in a good location. Although we did find the airconditioning seemed to be set at heating only (during winter anyway), I found that turning it off actually helps cool the room. Only minor point as well is wifi is not great (although free), likes to disconnect regularly but could be from construction going on.Enjoyed the traditional breakfast included with very polite and friendly staff. Will definitely return when visiting Tokyo again!

It is the middle of the night as I write this review... And venting is the only thing on my mind right now... The Air con cooling system isn't working and the heater seems to be working overtime (it feels far worse than the Indian summer - and suffocating! ) While the management helped by opening the windows in my room, It's close to freezing outside... So I'm sure the next time the temp wakes me up, it will be cause it's too cold... In short , not a nice experience.. And the knowing response I got from front desk makes me feel they know all bout this and see this all the time... The hotel is cute, but come here at your own peril and if you're game for a sleepless night!

This was our second stay at Granbell and we were just as happy as the first time. The hotel is located nearby to the Shibuya crossing. There's a family mart convenience store nearby and plenty of restaurants to choose from. The included buffet breakfast is more than sufficient and the rooms are modern, clean and quiet. The staff are very friendly and made bookings to different restaurants for us. This is the perfect place to stay in Tokyo.

This hotel was ideal for our stay - perfect location, great price and very comfortable. The rooms are small but with key amenities and right in the heart of Shibuya (near the train station, etc.). The staff were very helpful and the rooms were quiet. Breakfast was good - esp. the buffet on the main floor of the hotel. We would definitely stay here again.

What a great little hotel! Newly renovated, modern chic rooms - a little on the small side but the norm for Tokyo! Great location, walking distance from all that lively Shibuya has to offer. Super friendly staff. A great experience, highly recommended.

We stayed at the Shibuya Granbell Hotel for four nights in mid January. First, the good: The location is amazing. Shibuya is a great neighborhood and it is very close to the center of it all. The service was amazing from the very beginning. We were greeted warmly and the staff was amazing about the reason of our stay, our honeymoon! What they don't tell when you book is the fact that the hotel is under construction. As we walked in, the first thing we saw in the small lobby was a dividing panel trying to disguise the mess of reconstruction. We were able to see a pile of mattresses lying there, not pretty. The staff was so good to us that this was not a major issue. If we hadn't been treated so well, I probably would have complained.If the hotel is under construction, the guests should be advised when they make a reservation.All in all, it was a good stay. It will probably look pretty cool once the renovations are finished.

Sebastian P
New York City, New York

review_body: I like the Shibuya district. This hotel has a nice restaurant downstairs, and the people who work there are very kind and polite. The decoration is modern, and the rooms and view are nice. Breakfast is simple (we got the Japanese, not the Continental) but it was nice enough and it was free. We called ahead to book, and were upgraded to a suite due to a communication error, so we only saw a suite, which was very nice and had a good view.

It is close to the train station though you have to take the overpass (footbridge) which makes it a hassle if you have your big luggage with you getting off from the train station to the hotel.Difficult to look for the hotel but just follow the directions listed in their site. You can walk to the Shibuya Crossing and to Hachiko's statue from this hotel... maybe around 5-6 blocks.The room is small but I guess that's typical in Tokyo. The corridor to the rooms has dark light (I think that's by design) as if you are in club.

Good location, rooms standard size for Tokyo. Breakfast is ok - go for the first floor option. Decent option in heart of Shibuya has a bar attached. Use the lifts to take luggage over the walkway from the station

The rooms at Shibuya Granbell are small but is typical of any Tokyo hotel, if you take economical room. But in this hotel the rooms a brand new, modern and very comfortable, The staff are very helpful and speak English. Very near the Shibuya crossing and train station. A lot of restaurants, bar, store close buy. Free Wi-Fi in the room. For more money you can get a bigger room,. Ther3e is two restaurants attached to the Hotel, to take the free breakfast, and one is until 11 AM. There is also a small bar open late, were you can have a good choice of wine and some food, not so expensive. A lot of tourist information, and the staff will help you to find the route to the best attraction around Tokyo and the price. There is also in the lobby some good information about what happen in Tokyo. While we were there was information about the Sumo Tournament. . Excellent location. Excellent service. And very well appointed. Will go back on my next visit to Shibuya.

The location of this hotel is just perfect - a little bit away from the hustle and bustle of Shibuya crossing, yet close enough to get there, to the station, and to plenty of great shopping opportunities and excellent restaurants within a few minutes.We treated ourselves to the "View Bath Suite", which was a maisonette on a corner on the top floor and simply amazing. The lower area contained the huge comfy bed and a couch area with tv, plus a terrace (a rarity in Tokyo which we really enjoyed), the upper area contained the bathroom with separate toilet and a large round whirlpool. Two sides of the suite were surrounded by curtains, which could be moved aside with the click of a button to reveal a stunning view of Tokyo (especially at night, and when viewed from the whirlpool :-).Literally everything about this room was very clean and very modern & stylish.The reception desk was friendly and helpful. The only negative thing about this hotel is the elevator, which is extremely dark (and thus almost creepy). The corridors were quite dark, too, but not as bad.There are two breakfast options - one buffet-style Western breakfast on the ground floor which we found not so great, and a choice of Japanese or Western breakfast served in a nice setting on the 2nd floor, both of which were very tasty.I highly recommend this hotel, especially if you are looking for something a bit extraordinary for a change.

A great little hotel, right in the heart of Shibuya so you're walking distance to, the shops nightlife and some excellent eateries. The hotel was clean, a little noisy as it was undergoing refurbishment but everyone was very polite and accommodating - Most of the staff spoke good english and allowed us an early check in for no extra and giving us a couple of hours extra to allow us a late check out for a nominal fee. Breakfast was simple but fine and you can always go out for breakfast as you're so close to everything.Rooms are on the small side but if you plan to explore Tokyo you won't spend long in your room.And for the price I think it's a bargain. We'd stay again.

Stayed here for 8 nights, but would love to have stayed more! Staff here are most helpful and attentive, yet unobtrusive. Room was super clean and very comfortable, and the best thing - it was quiet! Free wifi was super fast, which the kids loved.Close to shops, restaurants and trains, and the famous Shibuya crossing! Don't forget to try the pizza in the annexed bar - Cona. So good.Can't wait to come back. Recommend highly.

Partner and I booked an Annex single for 10 nights. Hotel is modern, staff are extremely friendly and helpful. There's a laptop set up in the lobby for guests to use free of charge. Great location also -with central Shibuya crossing area only a short walk over the bridge.Room might be a bit on the small side for some people, but if you're not too fussed and clever with space then the hotel is the perfect choice. Would definitely book this place again.

It is a tad unfair for me to have the above title for this review, as you shall find out in a bit. I booked a comfort double for my two-night stay at the Granbell. It was a rainy afternoon when I got to the hotel and as I had arrived early, a complimentary umbrella was kindly provided by the hotel staff as I left to get some lunch nearby. I was allowed to leave my luggage (which was wiped dry by the attentive staff!) and on returning, I was told that they have prepared a very nice room for me. I didn't pay much attention to why that was until I stepped into my room. I was upgraded to the luxury suite - with space so large that when I showed the photo of my room to my Japanese friends they didn't believe that I was in Tokyo! The bed was very comfortable. The bathroom had a shower and a circular bath tub. Pity I was on a solo trip, as this could've easily been a romantic city getaway for two! Complimentary breakfast was either Japanese (on 2F) or Western at the cafe/bar just next to the hotel. Another plus point is the hotel's location. It was literally 5 minutes walk from the Shibuya Scramble/Hachiko exit of the Shibuya JR eki. Getting up the pedestrian bridge from Shibuya JR with luggage was not a problem as there are lifts (you need to keep an eye out on their location).I would definitely come back again (upgrade or not!) just because of the location.

This hotel has excellent service and location. The room's are tiny but it has everything you. It is very modern and quiet. You are near some great sights and some of the best sushi. The staff is very friendly and can speak English very well.

This hotel is a great place to stay as a jumping point to wander and explore Tokyo. We had a really positive experience staying here, the staff were so helpful & lovely, the room was equipped with everything we could need & the breakfast was super delicious. Loved the design touches and the location - it's all on the doorstep! Fab place and we would stay here again in a shot.

Shibuya Granbell is of typical Tokyo hotel room size but the rooms are incredibly comfortable. The staff are very accommodating and polite. There is a 7eleven and Lawsons very close by and are open all day, perfect if you feel like a midnight snack or drink! However, there are no signs at the front of the hotel apart from the massive doormat by the front door, look out for Cona restaurant which is connected to the hotel at the front.

In a quiet street close to Shibuya train station, Granbell Hotel is perfect to explore Tokyo. The Hotel is walking distance to a lot of shops in Shibuya, Harajuku and a bit further ahead Omotesando. By train or underground the all city is at hand. The rooms have nice design and are functional. Sleeping quality is very good.

Stayed for 5 days. Hotel is only 5-6 min away from Shibuya crossing. Very clean with all needed amenities, very comfy bed, very nice breakfast at Cona restaurant on the 0 level. Room was for two of us. Yes, it is a bit small when you want to unapack, but that is not bad at all.Would stay here again!

A trendy and modern hotel. The room was a good size, comfortable and very clean. The staff were friendly and helped us with directions. There were options for a western or Japanese breakfast; we went with western and it was good. The hotel is very close to Shibuya station and the crossing. It was a great base for exploring Tokyo and had plenty of restaurants and bars close by. I would readily stay at this hotel again.

A very hip hotel amidst a very hip district. Room size on the tiny side, very nice for a short stay, but if you have more than 2 medium-sized luggage pieces with you, you will face a very serious storage problem.I really like the hotel, despite the tiny rooms and boring breakfast.The breakfast options are okay, but the mediocre type of okay. There are 2: traditional Japanese breakfast and European breakfast buffet. Beware of the knives at the hotel's own pizzeria (where the European breakfast is served): they are not very sharp, to put it very mildly. There are tons of other breakfast/lunch and dinner options directly in the neighborhood. Also the Shibuya station is just a couple of minutes' walk away.

it's a tricky one. We were upgraded to a duplex urban suite which was amazing however we would have felt very differently had we been in the room we actually booked (premier double) from looking at the room size vs cost. The hotel is really well located in Shibuya in a cool area with loads of bars and restaurants in the surrounds. Hotel commonparts really dated and the staff were really difficult to deal with. They spoke hardly a word of English and didn't seem used to recommending anything or booking restaurants. Getting any information on local amenities took 15 minutes. It as like they had never been to Tokyo before. The western breakfast was ok but nothing special.

We absolutely loved our stay at the Granbell! We got upgraded to a cozy suite which was v. spacious with a downstairs lounge and upstairs bed, bathroom and walk in wardrobe. The location is perfect, less than 5 mins to Shibuya station, great access to Shibuya itself and also very close to Ebisu which, if you have a few days there, is worth strolling to for a more laid back, relaxed atmosphere with some great local bars. The choice of breakfast was good, we preferred the restaurant which you access from the 2nd floor. We turned up at the other one at around 10 30 and there was hardly any food left on the buffet. For location, cleanliness and space in the heart of Tokyo, I would highly recommend the Granbell!

The Granbell Shibuya met all our requirements. The room was good, the location fantastic (and the directions to the hotel were very good). Generally in Tokyo you do not spend a lot of time in your room - so this made the room all the better to come back to each night. The included breakfast was satisfactory.

a very well thought and made/designed rooms (especially for single ones).. quite small in area-wise; but very efficient in which you can find every need you may have in a room.. especially the bathroom is very-well thought.. totally clean, well-taken care of and have lovely, helpful staff either.. no need to mention about the location as it's in the heart of whatever you want..

We stayed at the Grandbell Hotel for 3 nights during our first trip to Tokyo.As expected, the room was small but it had all the necessities. It was spotless with a very comfortable and large bed, free wifi, quiet ambience, not much for a view from the room window; but as we used all the time we had exploring the city, we didn't need a "view".Also, as highlighted below, the breakfast arrangement was very good. We had the choice of traditional or Western breakfast (that was serviced to our table by a great gentleman). We found this to be a great way to start the daily activities.Hotel manager was extremely helpful, polite and friendly. He gave us many suggestions (including walking with us for 300 meters to a nearby soba noodle place) We couldn't have asked for more. Genuine service.Strongly recommended.

The hotel is very convenient. Room size was ok (small, but expected) but one complaint I have is that the bathroom stank of stale urine. Really disgusting and unexpected for Japan. I told them about it but they didn't seem to be able to do anything about it... Room 713 - avoid if you can.

Stayed for 3 nights in July.Excellent located in the quiet part of Shibuya and very near the Station. Arrived in late evening and missed the front door and entered through the side door. Stayed in a standard single room and it was really small and unable to open my luggage properly. Bathroom was also pretty small but functional, Window could be opened in the room. Breakfast was complimentary and only adequate. The safe was placed on top of the fridge and items got rather warm inside. Hissing noise came through underneath the door during my stay.

I spent 5 nights here to visit Tokyo. This hotel is simply great:- great location: 5 minutes walk to Shibuya station (JR lines, subway lines, buses) ; main sights and famous Tokyo areas are reachable in less than 30 minutes by public transportation.- great neighborhood: surrounded by a lot of restaurants, bars & shops- perfect room: (i had a superior twin rooms at the top floor) clean, very spacious and very well decorated- good breakfast: choice between continental and japanese breakfast- helpful staff speaking english

Spent the first night in a standard room and then got an upgrade for the remaining 3 nights. Initial room was fine, but upgrade was stunning in an annex suite with a downstairs lounge and bedroom up. Huge big bathroom along with excellent amenities (an upgrade from the basics in our original room) The bed was great and we had big sliding window shades that opened up to a city view. Breakfast was included but nothing special so we ate elsewhere for the remaining days. Perfect location (100m from Shibuya station) and we were worried we might get lost as per other reviews but it wasn't a problem at all if you use the hotel instructions on the website! Thank you!

Great location close to the Shibuya crossing. We were able to check in at 1am after our late flight and the staff were really friendly. Included breakfast was a choice of two restaurants but we preferred the buffet which had a great coffee machine. The room was perfect and bigger than we expected in Japan!

We stayed in the Modern Double room and loved it! Perfect size for 2 people and extremely clean! They cleaned the room everyday. The location was fantastic!! Right next to everything you need. Super short walk to the train station and famous Shibuya crossing. There is a little restaurant right outside the hotel that has people around all the time so felt really safe walking back to the hotel at night.We are going back in March next year and can't wait to see the staff again!I am from Perth if anyone has any questions.

I loved staying at this hotel. It had everything I needed and was within my budget. It is located about a 5 min walk from Shibuya station and this was great for navigating to all the spots I wanted to visit in Tokyo. It was close to the action but not so close that there was lots of noise. It was a very quiet hotel. I felt really safe walking back to the hotel at night after shopping in Shibuya or elsewhere.Breakfast was included in my room charge but I chose to get it while I was out in the mornings so can not provide information regarding that.Staff were helpful and spoke English well.The room was compact but well designed. Had lots of toiletries supplied, hair dryer, plus desk, tv, storage and a really comfy bed.I stayed here for 6 nights and would highly recommend it to anyone!

I've just finished my fourth stay at this little gem in Shibuya. Like all hotels in Tokyo, the rooms are small, but you won't get a better designed space than this one. The rooms are super comfy.. the service is impeccable. Oh, and you also get breakfast thrown in. Head to level 1 for the french toast. The ground floor breakfast isn't quite as good. Hint: check out the long-stay plan for any stays over 3 nights.

This hotel ticks all the boxes:1. reasonable price for a clean and good size room;2. free breakfast with choices - Japanese or Western3. Friendly and helpful staff4. Convenient location - 5 mins walk from Shibuya station and very easy to find (follow the map on the hotel's website)Will definitely go back next time when I visit Tokyo again.

Nice big rooms, with ensuites that were extremely clean. Great value. Location right was easy to get to (a little hard to find being our first time there!) Funky and modern looking. Breakfast options were great - even for us vegetarians.

SoloJoe
New York City, New York

review_body: Few blocks away from Shibuya station, with great restaurants, shops and caffes nearby. Main department stores are around and it's easy to experience the Shibuya super crowded crossing. Staff is super helpful and the hotel offers a reasonable breakfast. Clean and modern rooms

My husband and I stayed at more of a business class hotel in Shinjuku prior to arriving at the Shibuya Granbell. The boutique design was a nice change, albeit with a few quirks. We were amused by the dark, dimly lit elevator and hallways which felt like a night club. Thankfully, our room was more cheerful but definitely showed some wear. We referred to the bathroom as our "space capsule." The bathroom was separated from the sleeping area by a clear window with a curtain; you can have as much privacy, or not, as you want. There are two dining options with the breakfast voucher. The 2nd floor restaurant has Japanese and Western sit down meal options and was OK. The Cona Cafe on the street level was also OK and served continental style breakfast but with a good espresso self-serve machine -we ate here 2/3 mornings just to have decent espresso. Otherwise I think they served leftover food from the day before. The Cona Cafe is actually a pizza and wine bar. There's a good selection of small restaurants and cafés near the hotel if you don't feel like walking to the busy Shibuya crossing area. Getting our wheeled luggage from Shibuya Station to the hotel was no problem. Use the elevators up/down from the pedestrian overpass from the south entrance of the station. We asked for directions to the hotel from the information counter at the train station and it was very straightforward. The staff was always friendly and helpful and allowed us to leave our luggage there after checkout while we spent the day in Kamakura before our departure flight from Haneda later that evening. For as popular as this hotel is with other reviewers, it felt very private and quiet.....we barely ran into any other guests during our stay in August. The quiet was welcome after the crowds of Shibuya. For the convenience we would stay here again.

Been to japan gazillion timed, stayef at gazillion hotels, this one is one of the best i must say :)Room wise, similar to hotel rooms all over jaman, super tiny, but they serve decent breakfast, nothing major, but decent enough to help you start the day.The thing i lve the most about this hotelmis the location, literally stone throw away from shibuya stn :)

This hotel is centrally located in Shibuya. We walked around confused for a while but were eventually able to find it. The rooms are clean and comfortable and have some pretty touches (e.g., curtain). The staff are professional and friendly. They helped us ship our luggage to hold at the Narita airport while we went off to Kyoto for a few days. Only downside was the rather lackluster breakfast. There are two options-a restaurant upstairs and a cafe downstairs-but neither one was very enticing. Overall, a comfortable base for exploring Tokyo.

As Tokyo was the last real stop on my trip around Japan I decided to go boutique instead of business. A mistake.The Granbell Shibuya has great instructions on their website until you are within a few feet of the hotel when it is hard to find. The plants have overgrown the hotel sign!! Look for the Italian restaurant instead.Once I go there the staff were very friendly and spoke the best English that I had come across in Japan. I got the key to my single room and went up. It was small but I expected that. Within about 3 minutes I was headed back downstairs to request a move. Small is fine, dirty is not. The walls next to the bed had stains on them. The staff said coffee- I'm not so sure. The carpet was dirty as was the wall next to the desk.I was moved to a slightly larger room without a desk in the annex. It was clean and the bed was firm and comfortable. The wifi was strong and the room although very oddly configured was comfortable enough.The shower was excellent which was good as it was still stinking hot out and in the dirt of Tokyo I was showering twice a day.Breakfast isn't worth the bother. The staff were in a perpetual bad mood. The coffee was good but the machine temperamental. The croissant were stale and there wasn't much more to it.Great location - disappointing hotel. I will go back to business hotels next time I am in Tokyo.

Clean and stylish room. Great in room amenities. Decent breakfast. Superb location but be sure to locate on map and go to correct exit. Shibuya station has several exits and they are far apart. I made the mistake of not locating hotel on map and spent nearly 1.5hours looking for hotel (locals gave confusing directions) plus it was raining. Do note entrance of hotel is inconspicious (too stylish :P) It is a huge wooden door that doesn't look like a door and swings both ways. While location is superb, do note you have to take the overhead bridge (no other way/not that I know of) to cross over to hotel from Shibuya station. You gotta take the stairs. There are elevator but both broke down when I was there for the 2 nites. Sheesh! If you are not a smoker, please avoid the smoking room at all means. I thought it was nothing until I enter the room. I had to change the room to non-smoking which was available for 1 nite and second nite I had to pay to upgrade to have a deluxe non-smoking room but it is a lovely room. Service is excellent and has very honest staff. I left my adaptor and charger in first room and only realised late second nite and staff delivered to my room (kept it for me) right away when I called to ask. I left my wedding band in room (horrors), checked out and left for airport. I only realised upon reaching airport and quickly sent an email to hotel. The staff responded within the hour and found my ring! I was so relieved. Hotel kept ring until my friend went to retrieve it! Thank you Shibuya Granbell and all its dedicated staff!

We thought the hotel was amazing, right in the heart of the action. The rooms are perfect for base camp and the hotel restaurant and bar are sensational. the staff and food are amazing. I am so glad we stayed here, the batting cage next door was an unexpected highlight

I just spent 3 nights in a single room at the Granbell. If you are a solo traveler, not planning to spend much time in your room, and need a convenient base from which to explore Tokyo, look no further. The room was clean and efficient, quiet and comfortable. It had modern japanese touches and seemed newish. The location cannot be beat - it's 3 minutes from the Shibuya train station which connects easily to every part of tokyo either directly or with one transfer. The breakfast is mediocre but is fine for a quick bite before filling up on delicious local food the rest of the day. The front desk staff's english is sufficient, but don't look to them much for advice on Tokyo.

My friend and I stayed in this hotel for about a week, with two annexe single rooms. The rooms were comfortable and cozy, small by Western standards, but fine for central Tokyo. While the rooms are starting to show a little bit of age, they are still fine and worth their price. The staff were helpful and friendly.The hotel is just minutes walk from the hustle and bustle of Shibuya and its station. However, being south of the action places it in a quieter neighborhood. As far as I'm concerned, this makes it a perfect place from which to explore Shibuya and Tokyo.The only issue I had with this hotel was the breakfast, which was limited in range and size. However, the deal I booked gave me breakfast for free so I'm not going to complain too much! It's fine to get you going for a day of sightseeing.Overall, a perfectly located, nice hotel.

We stayed at the hotel for one week while visiting Japan. The room was small for 2 people, there wasn't much walking space or an area to leave the suitcases. The room was clean; however, they only cleaned it once while we were there, which was annoying. The location of the hotel is excellent, you are close to the metro station and to the shibuya center/downtown. We would go walking to Shinjuku, it wasn't a 5 minute walk but it was still close enough to walk to. The hotel reception was nice and helpful. I only tried out their breakfast once and it was good, nothing special.

We stayed in a Premiere double room, which was large for Tokyo rooms, and managed to accommodate the baby cot provided for our 2-year old, which was nicely made up with Winnie the Pooh sheets and blanket. If you don't need a cot, there is a small couch and TV, so room would feel very spacious. The bathroom was also very large, with an open style shower with two shower heads to choose from. Bath was big too.The hotel is very close to Shibuya station and a short walk to all of the main shops, yet the area feels slightly more quiet (in a good way!) It is a quaint street with several restaurants and a convenience store just around the corner. Hotel staff were extremely welcoming. It felt like they made an effort to get to know you. They immediately offered us umbrellas if it was raining outside and gave very good recommendations for dinner. Breakfast was included. We always had the buffet downstairs, where we enjoyed cereal, toasted croissants with jam, toast with scrambled eggs and yoghurt. It is simple with not a lot of selection, but still offered a great start to the day and was much easier than trying to eat out each morning. The jazz music and smell of pizza dough cooking (it becomes an Italian restaurant/ bar later in the day) were nice too.I would definitely stay at this hotel again.

Located right in the centre of Shibuya but on a quiet street away from the madness, this is a great hotel with lovely clean and modern rooms. We thought the reception was in need of updating, and the breakfast is not great, however overall this hotel is great value for money compared to other hotels in central Tokyo and we had a brilliant stay. We would recommend it!

Tokyo hotels can be a challenge, especially at the last minute, and especially more if it's a weekend. So even with the choices being quite slim, I'm extremely glad I found the Granbell Hotel in Shibuya. It's located about 150m from Shibuya station, clean to a fault, and not too difficult to find. The staffs are great and can speak English, Japanese, and even some Korean and Chinese it seems. Pros:-Location-Cleanliness-Great room with tons of amenities. -Breakfast was good with two options to choose from: Western (served in the 1st floor bar) and Japanese (on the 2nd floor). -Wifi is good, although a little weak in the lobbies. -Excellent price for the location, quality of the room, and the fact that this is Tokyo. Cons: -Single room could use some natural light. The only window was in washroom, and was not that large. -Probably difficult to find for those who are not familiar with Japan or Asia in general. Great hotel and definitely would love to come back, albeit in a larger room, although I have no complaints about the size because it is to be expected in Japan.

Booked an annex single room and although while a little small, it had everything you could need for a decent hotel stay. The room was spotless and bed was very comfortable.The location was great because it was on a quiet street within walking distance to the activity of Shibuya crossing, restaurants, nightclubs, and shopping. The staff could speak English very well and was extremely helpful in assisting with any questions about the area.

We stayed in this hotel for 6 nights, for the price range this is a very good hotel. The room we stayed in wasn't very big but i guess thats a Tokyo thing. The location of the hotel is very good, its located in a quiet area very close to the famous Shibuya crossing. There are quite a few bars and restaurants close. The room was very clean although quite dark, there was a lack of natural light. We were let down by the hotel's breakfast offering, I can't remember if i paid extra for this or not but its really not worth extra. It consisted of pre-cooked eggs in a bucket sort of thing that really didn't look appetising at all, bread, croissants, pasta salad and dodgy hot dogs. All in all we had a very pleasant stay at Granbell, staff were very nice and the room was nice.

I stayed here for one night with my partner and my parents, after arriving after 10pm on a flight from Australia. We stayed in two non-smoking "Comfort Double" rooms on the 8th floor. Despite it being so late and us being a group of obviously tired Westerners, the staff were lovely - handing several towels across the counter as we'd just been soaked by rain. The hotel was great for my first time in Japan: it was clean, VERY well situated (3 minute walk from Shibuya station, just two blocks from famous Scramble crossing)and the staff spoke decent English (I wouldn't expect anything more) and were super helpful - checking in and out was easy with our total lack of Japanese.. The room itself was bigger than I expected (still small, but it is Japan) and although it was very Western-style itself, the hotel is surrounded by cute little ramen shops, lanterns and neon lights so you definitely know you're in Tokyo, not in a little Western bubbleThe beds were comfortable (nice and firm. my partner found the pillows too small though), bathroom very clean, wifi was fast and didn't require any extra cabling or routers - just the password given with the room key. Breakfast was included, but wasn't anything special - if you're not keen on OK croissants and below average bacon and eggs, head to the many surrounding places. Our view wasn't anything stunning (central Shibuya in a cheap-ish room) but still afforded neon billboards and a cute rooftop bar with fairylights below us.Very glad we decided to stay in Shibuya. It's an interesting part of Tokyo on its own, and is close to places like Harajuku, Meiji Shrine and Yoyogi Park - about 3km, which we gladly would have walked if it wasn't raining but went for a 4 minute train instead. Also not far from Shinagawa when we needed to catch the Shinkansen out of Tokyo.

To begin, this hotel has a decent location just two blocks from Shibuya crossing. It is in a quiet part of the area which is rare and that made it a good hub to explore Tokyo from. This review's poor rating has to do with the condition of the property and the amenities. I am not sure how old this hotel is but it has seen better days and is not maintained to the standard of most properties we stayed at in Japan (or Japan which is quite clean everywhere) . It is in the category of "design hotel" and we sprung for a two-level suite. This was a substantial expense and we thought it was worth it to be able to rest after a long flight. Overview: The staff were pleasant and efficient. They helped us with directions and were responsive. That is what saved the stay for me.The property was very dirty, dust bunnies everywhere, duct-tapped vents, art crooked, and whole sections of the common areas were shut off from the public by stacks of furniture and other barriers. The hotel seems to have abandoned the bar and turned it into a storage area. The carpeting throughout is so worn and stained that it looked 25 years old. It was the same with our room. Painted surfaces were chipped, the carpet had many stains and the nap was worn down to the padding in places - the furniture showed a lot of wear for leather and the padding in the sofa frame had lost its resilience - not comfortable. The upstairs patio was filthy and festooned with odd plastic plants, also very grimy and bleak. They offer free breakfast which we thought was a perk but was not worth eating. It consisted of bowls of yogurt, eggs, or toast or pre-made combo plates in a sad upstairs dining area which used to be a restaurant of some kind. We skipped it the last two days and went to a charming coffee shop (chain) next door.All that being said, the shower room was very nice as was the view from the patio. I am sorry Shibuya Granbell but it is time for a major makeover and upgrade of your property.

Stayed here for 1 night. It was a small, clean room packed with everything required. Staff was kind enough to provide a non-smoking room upon request. Friendly staff, easy check in and check out. Close to the Shibuya station and cosy environment.

My two nights at Shibuya Granbell were plenty comfortable : nice bed, super shower, deluxe toiletries, fun decor, small frig, speedy elevators. The hotel was clean. The staff was polite. Cooked breakfast served in 2F restaurant was good; but the breakfast buffet in 1F Cona cafe was mediocre (cold eggs and sausage).Booked via Agoda for USD $140/night (single room incl. breakfast and taxes), I would recommend the Granbell to others seeking a convenient base in Shibuya.

I liked this hotel and will return, but only with the early bird discount, which saved us about AU$50 a night. The location is great, the staff are helpful and I found their English very good. Breakfast was included but wasn't anything to write home about. There's free LAN internet which was easy and fast. We stayed in a modern double to start with - it's small but not too small, and we enjoyed it. Don't get any smaller for a couple, unless you have no luggage! Then we moved to the Bath View Suite, which had magnificent views, but was a little shabby for a AU$600 a night room (we paid less with the discount - but still). Stains on the carpet and chips out of the furniture where suitcases have knocked it - not going to ruin your holiday but you expect more for that price. Plus the bathroom floods badly. So while it's a great hotel - don't pay full price!

It was my first trip to Japan and I didn't know what to expect, especially when most people say that Tokyo is expensive and the rooms are small. Granbell is amazing! Great value for money and perfect location. It's on the quieter side of Shibuya which means you get a good night sleep, always. The rooms are perfect and I loved having a double bed to myself haha! They were always cleaned during my 10 day stay, staff were so wonderful and friendly. If you can't speak Japanese, don't worry the people here are so helpful and you will be able to get by. I loved that breakfast was included everyday and there was a choice of two restaurants, there's a buffet on the ground floor which was so cute and casual or you could go to the second floor and enjoy a set meal at the Japanese restaurant. There are three sets to choose from, traditional japanese, french toast or western breakfast. Wifi was provided and was very fast and reliable.It's about a 5-10 walk to the Shibuya station so you can get around really easily. I will definitely be back and I would highly recommend this hidden gem! Best value for money in Shibuya.

We spend a week at this hotel in the view bath suite! Upon arrival there was a problem and the manager of the hotel reacted in a very efficient way to make us forget quickly about it. The rest of the stay was fantastic.The room was really big and it was so amazing to relax in that big bath after a long day of visiting that exciting city. Waking up with thst amazing view on Shibuya, having a drink in the evening on the terrace... Super romantic

I had the pleasure of staying once again at the Shibuya Granbell this past January. As I mentioned in my review last year, Tokyo is surprisingly lacking in boutique hotels and this little spot is one of the great ones. It is modern and tidy and located just a five-minute walk from the craziness of Shibuya Crossing but on a quiet side street where you can actually get some sleep.Last year I stayed in one of the tiniest but cleverly functional rooms I’ve ever been in and despite its diminutive size I was happy to re-book this year because the hotel was such a great home base.This year my girlfriend and I, sick with pneumonia, dragged our skis through Shibuya station and the rainy streets, past the out-of-order elevators that normally make the sets of stairs one has to navigate to get across the highway between the stations and the hotel manageable. When we arrived at the hotel with our massive pile of gear in tow we were simultaneously soaked, sweaty, freezing, hot and miserable. Thankfully, the wonderful Mr. Hirohiko Tsukamoto, the sub manager of the hotel, greeted us. After quietly checking us into our room, he informed us that he had a treat for us. Expecting a bottle of water or perhaps some tea, we were surprised when he told us that he had a special room for us that was “a little larger than the regular you booked.” This, it turned out, was the understatement of the trip!Mr. Tsukamoto, taking pity on the two sick and miserable Americans, quietly upgraded us to one of the hotel’s two story penthouse suites. To describe this room in is words is a challenge so please check out my photos.With two-story glass over looking Shibuya, the room is a visual stunner both day and night. The downstairs has a lovely sitting area with a bar and a huge flat screen, and looks out over the city. Gorgeous modern stairs ascend from there across the glass wall and up to the bedroom, which is an oasis in the city. The bed is heavenly and the desk, build of rich, warm hardwood, is set into the wall and faces out over the city. The wood paneling slides over the huge window, lest the light disturb your sleep. There are built in cabinets and drawers everywhere, lights, controls and the like clearly designed to make the suite a “home away from home,” which is exactly what Mr. Tsukamoto told us he wanted it to be for us. Of course, seeing all this comes before you step into the bathroom, which was itself the size of the room we’d booked. There was huge closet, a double vanity and a glass-enclosed WC with the fanciest of the Japanese robo-toilets that quite literally did it all for you. Drawers of toiletries were at your disposal as were piles of lush towels and robes. There was perfect and huge glass enclosed shower with both a rain head and a sprayer wand. And then there was the soaking tub: large enough for two people, L shaped, with one glass wall overlooking both the living room and, beyond the stairs, the city itself through the two story windows, it was an unforgettable experience to lay in the steaming water and recover after a winter’s day touring Tokyo.All in all we cannot say enough positive things about the Granbell, the suite and especially Mr. Tsukamoto. After two weeks skiing in Hokkaido, our days in Tokyo were the perfect end to a wonderful trip! If you need to stay in the Shibuya area and want the personal touch of a small and friendly boutique, this is your place. And if you can afford one of the top floor suites, you will not be disappointed.

My husband and I stayed at the Granbell Hotel Shibuya for x4 nights in the single Annex non-smoking room. This small but perfectly formed hotel made the perfect base for x2 people for a short stay. The bed was comfortable and the rain shower had very good pressure. The reception staff were very helpful and had maps/directions to local areas. They also helped us to book restaurants and treatments during our stay. Highly recommend and we would definitely book on our next visit.

Shibuya Grandbell Hotel is clean and decent, but it has the tiniest room for a single person and a bit of a walk and climb on the overhead pedestrian bridge upon arrival from the Haneda bus limousine drop off at a Shibuya Mark City. At first it is difficult to find the hotel. It's on a tiny street, not far from the overhead bridge.The toilet is quite modern and a bit of a fair space for a single occupancy. Power shower! :) The aircond in the room was warm, even after complaining to the front desk about it. Nevertheless the hotel is a good ground for your base in Tokyo and the heart of Shibuya. Stayed for a night.

We stayed in the annex part of the building in the back and it was fine. Nice view from 7th floor. Top marks for location, Shibuya is an amazing place to explore. Very easy to find if you follow the directions on the website. Breakfast was nothing special but the espresso was good. Good atmosphere in the pizza/bar restaurant, we didn't try the other one in back. The staff was nice and their English was very good - we live in a part of Japan where hardly anyone speaks English so we really appreciate Tokyo for that. And the shopping :)

We found this hotel to be very convenient to everything - Shibuya station, restaurants, shopping, Shibuya station… From Shibuya station, you have to go over the overpass to get to the other side. There are lifts to take you up so you don't have to haul your luggage up the stairs, however note that the lift shuts at 10pm. Staff were friendly when we checked in late at night. There were no big signs to the hotel so you could easily miss it. We found it because a passerby stopped to help us and googled on his phone where the hotel was (look out for a big white square structure at the front). The front entrance/door to the hotel is pretty cool! We went mid March and it was still chilly. The room was well heated, too well in fact that it got hot in the middle of the night. It would be useful if English instructions were provided for the air con. We left the air con off for 2 nights which didn't bother us.The room we had was small but ok for 2 people with medium size suitcases and some carry on. The bed was comfortable and the room was a little dark. We were staying for 5 nights but as we're only sleeping in the room and would be out all day (sometimes until 11-12pm), we didn't need an overly large room. We were on the third floor and looked out onto a street where you could see passerbys. You could not hear any outside noise or trains or traffic.Japanese tv was fun to watch but we wanted to watch some English speaking programs too, especially staying for 5 nights. Breakfast was nice, there is a Japanese and Western menu. We had the Japanese breakfast most days and it was nice: rice, miso soup, packed seaweed, seasoning, mackerel, tofu, preserved radish to name a few. The Japanese menu was the same most days, i.e. mackerel was served each day, so we would have liked a change (when you eat the same breakfast for 5 days, it loses it's appeal). The Western was a bit average (ham and salad with a few other side dishes).Shibuya Granbell is also close to a 7Bank ATM (7Eleven bank) for travellers wanting to withdraw cash out.All in all, we would recommend this for anyone wanting to stay in Shibuya. It is very conveniently located in a quiet street to everything you could possibly want :)

Shibuya Granbell was well priced & located (about 5mins walk from the huge Shibuya Station). However, it is worth noting that if you're hauling luggage from the station, you will need to navigate 2 lots of stairs on the overpass that links the station to the hotel side of the road. As I'd arrived via limousine bus, which drops off at Cerulean this wasn't an issue, as it's literally 2mins around the corner.I'd booked a premiere twin, knowing how small Japanese hotel rooms can be ... and frankly because it wasn't that much more expensive. I'm glad I did, as it was really spacious - plenty of room for 2 people & luggage ... plus lots of hanging space. It's also the only hotel I've stayed at in Japan that had an in-room safe. The bathroom was also very roomy; with separate shower & bath.As to the downsides, which ultimately have lowered my rating [as I just didn't find my stay at all restful]. The bed was really uncomfortable; I didn't have one night of uninterrupted sleep because the mattress discomfort literally woke me up each night.As did the room heating ... even with the in-room air conditioner turned off, there must have still been some filtering in from the stifling common hall. The only way to get some relief was by opening the window for a while, which thankfully Japanese hotels still allow (its pretty much extinct in other countries).Overall - good value & location, but not sure I'd book again as a good nights sleep is pretty important after big days spent walking around Tokyo !

I stayed in this little hotel for four nights, and while the location was very good and the price modest, I would never go here again. During my stay, I noticed that there was a laundry service mentioned on the paper they give you at check in, and that there were plastic laundry bags available in the desk drawer of the room. Since I was staying for some time, I decided to send a few things down: just a pair of pants and a few shirts and socks. I brought the laundry down to the front desk in the morning, the guy said ok, and they called me up around 8pm that night to pick it all up. No problem. Upon check out, however, they suddenly inform me that I owe ¥5,400 (about $53) for the laundry service, and I was shocked. I'm 100% confident that there was no mention of any price for the laundry service on anything in the check in materials or room, something which the lady at reception did not dispute. Maybe I have strange expectations, but I think that before a merchant can charge you money for something, they should alert you as to what the price is likely to be--or at the very least that there is a price. That way the customer knows he or she is entering into a commercial transaction. This hotel did neither, and that strikes me as sleazy and dishonest, not to mention unfair. If I knew the laundry wasn't free like the coffee or bottled water they give you, I wouldn't have used it. All they had to do was put a few words in the check in materials or the room somewhere that the laundry service costs money, that's all. If I had had a bit more Japanese and wasn't in such a hurry at the time, I would have refused to pay and argued with them about it, since ¥5,400 is a lot of money to me (especially for a small load of laundry!).  But as it was, I paid them and resolved never to go there again.  Who knows what else they might secretly decide costs several thousand yen.

The hotel is conveniently located just 3 minutes walk from Shibuya station and shopping district. It is surrounded by lots of eating places, convenient stores and even a hair salon.The staff speaks English, and the room, although a bit small, is functional. I had a very restful sleep on the bed. Very nice and comfortable. I would definitely go back to stay at the Granbell again.

Great hotel highly recommend it and will come back for my next trip. The rooms are small, but the bed is extremely comfy and the bathroom is very clean. Great heater aswell. Staff were very friendly and helpful and could all speak perfect English There is a small bar attached to the hotel. Great spot to start a night out. 5min walk to the heart of shibuya and train station.

Stay in this hotel for 1 night. Hotel is strategically located.. 5min walking distance from shibuya train station and other attractions.. surrounded by cafes and shops... Hotel staff is awesome!! Very helpful and speak English. Room were abit small but very cosy... Breakfast was nice.. we opt for the japanese set breakfastDefinitely will return to stay again!!

This hotel was a little difficult to find at first if you arrive via jr shibuya. The main doors are to the hotel is hidden next to a tapas type bar. They dont look like doors, but more of a wooden partition. My tip is to go up the pedestrian overpass and walk down the side where the tennis building is. There are lifts also.Room size is fair for this standard of hotel, however they must get a lot of people through as my room carpet was stained with cig. burns.

Having landed at Narita in the middle of a snow storm, we eventually managed to get to the Shibuya station via the Airport Express and subway. The hotel was easy to find and well within walking distance from the station and the check in process was quick and easy - the staff were lovely.The room itself was great - we stayed in a Modern Double and there was plenty of room (by Tokyo standards). The decor and overall styling of the hotel and rooms was really cool and modern.Everything was neat and tidy with enough room to stow our bags out of the way. We were only really in the room to sleep and shower and it lived up to all expectations - the bed was very comfortable and the shower was roomy (again by Tokyo standards). The quality complimentary toiletries were a nice touch.The location is fantastic - literally just minutes walk to the centre of Shibuya!Even though we were on a fairly low floor there was very little noise from outside and it was wonderful waking up and seeing all the snow outside. We had the complimentary breakfast in the restaurant attached to the lobby - we opted for the 'western set' which was delicious.Next time we are back in Tokyo we will definitely stay again.

This place had an amazing location. Shibuya is a great district, with nice restaurants and busy people. We went here for a business trip, and received great service from the personel in the lobby. We will choose this hotel again.

We have just stayed at Shibuya Granbell Hotel. The staff are so friendly and helpful, always so happy and ready to help in anyway. The rooms are very small (only reason this didn't get 5 star). We are travelling to the snow so we have two snowboard bags and a suitcase. Our snowboard bags have to go in the bathroom so we have enough space to walk around. But it's a laugh and we are managing. Some nice mod-cons like heated mirror so when bathroom is all steamy you can still see yourself. Nice little toiletries in the bathroom. Beds seem hard at first but they are actually really comfortable. The room was very hot but we found you can actually open the window (snowing outside so we only opened a crack and it was perfect!) The hotel serves a delicious Japanese traditional breakfast or western styles. Both are delicious and fresh. The pizza/wine bar downstairs is also good to relax and the girl was really friendly. All in all this is a great hotel. Yes the rooms are small but you are in the middle of the city and in a great location. The service is so good and the hotel has everything you need. I would come again- but with less baggage!

i was hesitant to write a review because i'd like to keep the shibuya granbell hotel a secret. tokyo is known for being one of the most expensive and crowded cities in the world so naturally hotel rooms are more costly and smaller than average. while the rooms are small, the shibuya grandbell hotel more than makes up for the lack of space by offering a great value, chic interiors, free breakfast, nice staff, and an amazing location in the heart of shibuya. the hotel's website has step by step instructions with photos on how to find the hotel, which was incredibly helpful. we took the n'ex from the airport, which when combined with their directions, arrival was a breeze, even after a 16 hour flight and crazy jetlag. tip: if for some reason you forget the directions, once you arrive in shibuya look up - the hotel is well-marked. in my opinion, the hotel's location is without question the best and i could not imagine staying anywhere else. shibuya is a fantastic place to stay, but there are not as many options of lodging compared to other locations in the city. (i found shinjuku to be sleezy yet sterile, and other neighborhoods were not as convenient.) the granbell is in the heart of it all, yet without any of the craziness, noise or long walks that you'd have to deal with at most of the other hotels in shibuya. there are countless restaurants and bars within walking distance and it is hard to find a bad meal. the bathrooms were great, the ubiquitous high-tech japanese toilet, lots of toiletries, and a combo bath-shower. overall, very functional use of space. breakfast, which was included in the room rate (and a huge benefit while in tokyo), was offered at two locations. we chose the upstairs restaurant (a la carte) each time, which offered three options, two western and one japanese. both food and coffee were of higher quality than expected and the service was quick. the staff were incredibly helpful and spoke enough english to make communication easy. what's not to love about the shibuya granbell? some travelers will be shocked at the size of the rooms. for a couple who wanted to spend most of our time outside, the comfort double was not a problem at all. but i couldn't imagine bringing a family and staying in those rooms... it would be close to impossible. can't wait to plan a return trip!

I stayed at the Shibuya Granbell Hotel as an independent traveler in November 2013 for 7 nights. Due to changes in my schedule, I ended up with an Annex Single Smoking room on the 4th level.As I also stayed in Sakuragaokacho during my previous holiday in Tokyo, finding the hotel was a breeze. The check-in process was seamless and I must compliment the cleaners for making a smoking room feel like an non-smoking one. The front desk staff was professional enough to bring me to the room for my approval before confirming my check-in. Kudos! I am afraid the positive experience ended on the first day.My subsequent nights were a nightmare. The room I stayed in was, unfortunately, situated right above a bar and a rather busy small street. I was appalled that the bar without any consideration that there exists an hotel so closely opposite, blasted rock music at 11pm every night! As though that wasn't enough for the tired traveler - who deserved nothing less than a sound sleep - to deal with, it was even more shocking to hear noisy and drunkard salarymen yelling on top of their lungs after 'happy hour' at the wee hours, also without any consideration for sleeping guests.My deepest disappointment was with the front desk male staff who manned the hotel at night. It during the third night, when I was running a temperature, that I sought the staff to do something about the noise pollution but the literal 'shrug shoulders' response I got was the least I expected of Japanese hospitality. As a result of the disturbance, my sleep quality at Shibuya Granbell was very poor and that affected my holiday significantly. Furthermore, the free Wifi was lagging and one needs to be mindful of intermittent service. Breakfast came in the standard Japanese, American and French options daily with nothing outstanding to comment on.Indeed one will be living in Shibuya - merely 5 minutes to the JR Shibuya Station no less - but with the experience I had, I would rather be staying in a less exclusive area with the luxury of a good's night sleep and helpful staff to make a good holiday.

こんにちわ!　I stayed at the Granbell over new years holidays for 10 days and it was amazing. The hotel room was quite small (but it's japanese standard right?^^) but always very clean and the seeing-through shower is really nice. The location is absolutely fantastic, just 3 minutes away from Shibuya station. It took me a while to find it at the beginning, but just because you can see the hotel sign if you are coming down the street not going up ^^ but nothing bad. You can have breakfast both in the 2nd floor restaurant or at the bar on the ground floor (and both are very good). Overall it was very good and I highly recommend you to go there, you won't be disappointed!! ^^/

I find myself in Japan on many occasions and have stayed in many hotels in greater Tokyo. The Granbell Shibuya will be the one I will always come back to from now on. It is conveniently located within 10 minutes walk from the train station. Within minutes of the hotel you can be guaranteed to find anything you need including restaurants, shopping, banking, etc.The rooms are clean and relatively large (relative as compared to other hotel rooms in Tokyo) with all the amenities including an air purifier! I really like their interesting entrance. Go there and you will see what I mean.Breakfast at the Granbell was included. I find that the Japanese breakfast was much more impressive than the Western buffet near the lobby.By-the-way, if you have seen the movie Lost in Translation, there was a scene that was filmed in Shibuya. The location is 10 minutes walk from the hotel. Awesome!

others here have raved about this hotel. I meanwhile find it to be merely good to average. it certainly is nice and modern and the location is excellent. it should however be mentioned that service is rather cold and distant and that the two rooms I stayed in both only had one power outlet and very basic television programs. while I don't regret my stay here it won't be a place I will be raving about in the future.

Normally we stay in one of the larger hotels in downtown Shibuya, but this time we wanted a change. We were after something more intimate, a hotel with character, but still with a convenient location. Granbell offers all that and more. We loved the suite we had booked. Our room was quite spacious for Tokyo standards. Spread over two levels with an amazing bathroom. Free Wifi, complimentary breakfast, and a late check out. Just a short walk from the Cerulean Hotel (and a drop off point for the Limousine Bus from both airports), this hotel is a great option in Tokyo. Remember to book in advance to receive the best rates. You will also want to try to book one of the suits to maximise your room size. Make sure you check out the floor plan of each room type on their website. Apparently the small rooms are quite small, but the service and location of hotel will make up for the small floor space.

The rooms can be too small (in the annex) if you have a lot of luggage, but they are aesthetically more impressive than other hotels with mood lighting, a nice colour scheme and a comfortable bed. The bed was big enough for two even though the hotel describes it as a single. The water from the shower can also come directly from the ceiling and the toilet flushes itself. There is a bar downstairs and many restaurants nearby. It is also on the quieter side of Shibuya but within 10 minutes walk of the shopping areas. However, at first entrance to the hotel, the lobby seems too dark and allows smoking near the elevator. Also, the elevator and corridors to the hotel room are painted black with orange lighting and gives off the impression of a sleazy and unclean hotel. But when you enter the hotel room, it is bright with light and we were generally happy with our four nights at the Granbell hotel.Our only complaints about the room service was that they did not give us more tea, coffee and fresh teacups after we used them.

We were advised to stay at the Granbell Shibuya and it was a good tip. It is centrally located, the rooms are in the range of big, two areas to have breakfast (take the bar option at the reception-the ambiance is great and there is fresh fruit). The staff was extremely friendly and professional. The rooms were quiet and the design was super cool. If you want to be in Shibuya it is a very good trendy choice.

The rooms are small but you get what you pay for in terms of size for this hotel.Service was good, although the staff spoke limited English, and the rooms were cleaned and maintained well.Perfect location for seeing Shibuya and the rest of Tokyo (4 minute walk to Shibuya Station).

What a great hotel. Close to the shibuya train station, modern facilities, two restaurants, great breakfast choices, and easy to find! I loved the easy to read directions on the website on how to find the hotel. It was a BIG help. Shibuya is a great area to stay if you're young and with mates. It has heaps of great restaurant choices, shopping malls and is part of the JR train line. Staff were helpful and friendly. Room was small but comfortable. I would recommend this hotel to friends.

if you want to be right in the heart of Shibuya without spending a total fortune, than this hotel is a good bet. the rooms are small (though relatively standard for Tokyo) but they are well equipped and designed. there is absolutely no wasted space. the bed was really comfortable. the bathroom is decent and well stocked with all the basic travel necessities.the hotel has 2 restaurants, one Japanese and one pizzeria and you can choose to have the complimentary breakfast in either. I went for the Japanese place every day i was there and the breakfast was more than adequate- i was served quickly and was beautifully presented. the staff were helpful, though i suspect their English was relatively limited. They were really useful in providing directions within the area as well as advice on how to get to and from the 2 main airports.in close proximity to the hotel there are tons of little restaurants, as well as all the shopping venues Shibuya has to offer. in general, if you are looking for a decent place to stay without paying a fortune, this is a safe bet.

Great restaurant/drinks downstairs. Good situation peaceful area next to shibuya. The staff of the hotel are rude and uneducated. We asked for 15 minutes more of sleep day 1st of January and they wanted us to pay extra rate. One night the rooms were cheap and the next were expensive. Over all okay. I wouldnt recommended to anyone. The rooms are small and average.

Hotel was a great find. While our room was small it was very effectively designed so it was still comfortable. Breakfast was really nice (take the Japanese one) and it really helped us start our day properly. The staff is just wonderful. Very welcoming and extremely warm. Value for money and location are great. Would like to stay there again!

Great hotel, we really liked it! It was nice, clean and comfortable. Excellent location! Plenty of restaurants close by. Service was really great, English was good and they were really helpful. They even helped us cancel a booking in Japanese with another hotel as we couldn't make it due to Typhoon. The only thing that I didn't like was the breakfast but it was included so I guess I can't complain.

My husband and I checked in very late to this hotel. The staff were very pleasant and spoke good English. Our room was on the smaller side, but pretty standard for Japanese hotels. We really enjoyed the included breakfast, which was really filling and yummy (they have a Japanese and American style breakfast available). There were also complimentary bottles of water available in the room, which was a nice touch. There are lots of restaurants nearby, with the Shibuya train station a mere 5 minute walk away. Despite the proximity to the train station, the hotel is tucked away from the main road and the rooms are quiet. Definitely enjoyed my stay here.

This is our first trip to Japan and finally choose to stay at Granbell. We booked two rooms (daily breakfast and tax all inclusive), very good price. Love the neighbourhood. Location is good, close to JR Shibuya Station. Restaurants and shopping stores nearby. Free wifi and fast. Nice staffs, speak English quite well. Rooms are small but very clean. Bathroom with transparent glass door is inconvenient although there are curtains separating bathroom and bedroom. We enjoy our stay at Granbell, would definitely recommend this hotel.

First off, let me start by saying that it was my first time inTokyo and I had NO IDEA where to go. Also, I got the cheapest room. I went off a friends recommendation, she LOVED IT. Still does, so to each is own.The rooms are a lot smaller then they look, if you can believe that. The bathroom was super clean and had everything you could need, which was a plus. Clean bed, clean sheetsHowever, the rugs were stained , which is a peeve of mine and the room service was like non existent but I guess you get what you pay for - if i recall it was like $150 or something a night USD.Breakfast SUCKED and was a little sad. Kinda empty, sad staff, no love. Don't get me wrong, no one was rude just a little bored, sad, jaded, etc etc etc. I am from NYC so I am assuming that hotels in Tokyo are like one sin NYC. If you expect to stay in a nice hotel you in Tokyo, you better be ready to pay for it. Around $350ish USD is what i would assume decent hotel is around here.Location was really great though. Love Shibuya and super close to awesome shopping and almost all the train stations.I wouldn't be against staying here again but I am returning in December but I think i will try another hotel....

Stayed for 5 nights and loved the location, our room, the amazing shower and toilet and the little bar downstairs. Great small details like providing clothes freshening spray in the wardrobe, plus lots of toiletries. Wifi was fast and free bottled water replaced everyday. I tried the free western breakfast one morning but didn't bother getting up for it again. The pizza is good from the bar downstairs and the other food looked good too. Had a great night at the 'Hus & Wife Darts bar' opposite with a very entertaining owner. Its easy to walk to all the big shops and we found some other great bars 20 minutes or so walk away. We tried to stay one more night but they were fully booked on the Saturday so we ended up in the Intercontinental in Roppongi for twice the price but not as much charm. Would love to come back to the Granbell and Japan. Had such a great time.
