For the price, this place offered a truly outstanding level of service with a smile. I stayed at the Shibuya Granbell during my first ever trip to Japan. Check-in was a breeze. My room was cozy but had beyond the number of amenities one would expect for this price (extensive toiletries, much-needed water bottles on hand and replenished, etc). I received vouchers for a drink at their bar, along with breakfasts for each morning I was there. Also, the front desk staff helped make my bus reservation for returning to Narita. For being so close to Shibuya station and highways, the hotel was remarkably peaceful at night. I would absolutely consider staying at this hotel again should I return to Tokyo in the future.

Nice hotel located very close to the station over a set of pedestrian overpasses. Staff were good and pretty friendly with good English spoken. Room very stylish and bigger than expected in Tokyo with a full bathroom and fantastic power shower that's more typhoon than than rain. The restaurant downstairs is popular and did good western food if you are noodled out, there is a very cheap noodle place next door that was great though ordering was tricky.At the back of the lobby there is a bar that seemed pretty popular and was open late.Location is great, very close to all the shopping area and nightlife and once you get the station entrances wired it's incredibly easy to find.If you find the overhead walkways at the sout west station entrance it's just a matter of heading towards the big guitar shops over the expressway and the hotel is 150m from the lift access to the walkways.Would definitely recommend.

That hotel has a great location, close from Shibuya center. The rooms are design and clean. The staff was very nice and over helpful with us. And the price was really interesting. Overall a place to recommand if you visit Tokyo!

Within a short walk of Shibuya Station and Shibuya crossing, the location is excellent. The rooms are very small, but with so much on offer in Tokyo I barely spent any time in my room. Staff were friendly and helpful. The room was comfortable and clean, but I felt it was starting to get a bit tired. The bathroom amenities were excellent and plentiful. The breakfast on offer at the Japanese Restaurant (a choice of three meals, including French Toast) was superior to that on offer at the Western restaurant on the ground floor. I enjoyed my stay in Shibuya and the hotel was more than adequate and good value for the location.

5-10 mins walk to Shibuya JR station in a quiet and nice neighborhood, plenty of restaurants and convenient stores nearby. Clean rooms, nice staff and fair breakfast (only tried western). I booked a "premiere double" with my wife so rooms were not that small, but still were small for a "premiere" anything (maybe good enough for local standards and prices). Plenty of space for bathroom that could have been used for closets or the like. Would surely recommend it and come back again but keep your expectations lower when reading "premiere".

This hotel was listed in the american express magazine and even though american express didn't have the ability to book it the hotel and staff was fantastic. Clean comfortable and really the best experience in tokyo. I will definitely be back to this hotel.

The location is great but a bit hard to find, be sure to look up the map before leaving. Strangely, the sign to the hotel faces away from the approach from train station. Look back from time to time as you go uphill from the train station to make sure you don't miss it. The decor is trendy and looks like an Aloft hotel. Room was small but expected for Tokyo, it's functional and it was clean. Breakfast was included, nothing great but got the job done. One thing about Japan is they charge your about $10 for a few toasts, runny eggs, and coffee. So it's nice to have that without paying $10.

This hotel is well located near the Shibuya station, which is directly accessible by taking the Narita Express and on the JR line that can take you to many attractions. As with everywhere else in Japan, the staff was polite and helpful. I had asked them to assist in making a reservation for dinner and had no problem communicating in english. I was in a small double room with my boyfriend with 2 big suitcases. Due to the limited amount of space in tokyo, the room had minimal space to move around and open suitcases which was understandable. We were only there to sleep for 2 nights so we didn't care. Their other rooms look bigger from the pictures i have seen. The room was clean and had the basic amenities we wanted (room had free wifi). Daily breakfast was included in the room, and we really enjoyed the japanese style breakfast. I would recommend this hotel if you are simply looking for a great location to sleep at night within tokyo.

This is my second time staying in this hotel. Although its room is extremely small and somehow you almost can hardly find a space to open your luggage fully, it is a real bargain. It includes free wifi, and a nice complementary breakfast, which is the part I like most. It is in great location, too, which is just 5 minutes away from train stations. The room is clean and quiet.

I stayed 2 nights here as a solo traveller and was upgraded to a double room, which I thought was very spacious by Japanese standards, especially the bathroom, which had a tub. The wifi sometimes dropped out but mostly was fine. The TV only had Japanese channels. There is a small vending machine on the 8th floor.The bed was very comfortable, the room seemed quite new.The corridors are a bit too dark, and the breakfast was not very good. Packed breakfasts are not available. Email communication beforehand took a few days to be answered.The service was very good, front desk giving me lots of directions and having lots of maps. The hotel was in a very safe location.I thought overall it was very good value given the location in the middle of Shibuya.The hotel website has good photo directions.

We stayed here for 5 stayed and were so glad we did. The first night was in the executive suite because other rooms were booked out - very small separate living area with upstairs bedroom and bathroom. Bathroom was huge!! It had a bath which could easily fit 3 ppl. Unfortunately had to downgrade to double rooms, but it was still a good room. It was small as expected. Bed was comfy and shower was good. Great air con and wifi.Location is the best thing about this hotel. We liked that it was not in the centre of town but just 5 min away on the other side of Shibuya station. It was very convenient but not noisy, and put us closer to not so touristy restaurants. We recommend the noodles place next door and the izakaya across the road- yum!Service was good too. They helped us make dinner reservations and our next accommodation. They do take afew days to reply to emails though, which can be more efficient. Breakfast was fairly average. We're heading back there in 2 weeks time and are happy we booked this hotel again.

I stayed with family, in two rooms. The rooms, as with most in Tokyo, were small. This would've been okay, but they were also poorly lit and consequently the ambiance was not ideal. The breakfast was also relatively meager and could do with more variety (same thing every day, not buffet). The location was quite good, but the hotel itself has a lot of room to improve. Perhaps more ideal for young couples than families. It is a very touristy hotel - the hotel lobby is the type that is filled with languages from around the world. Maybe it just wasn't my kind of place.

After six visits we have found a hotel we would look forward to going back to. It's funky style immediately impresses you with the huge centre hung entry door and colour and art keeps that feeling throughout the hotel.Staff were friendly and obliging with good enough English to guide us around our colourful neighbourhood. Shibuya is the centre of lots of action but as well the subway is only 400m away. Coming from the airport you have a choice of the bus, which leaves immediately outside, or the train. We would do the train next time so we can get our jet lagged heads onto pillow quicker.Tokyo hotel rooms are tiny, but the Granbell was a decent size in comparison to others. Most importantly the beds were super comfy, the air con set just right for us, a bathroom with a powerful shower and a toilet you need a licence to drive. If only there was an iron in the cupboard. But with the great wifi reception that is a small complaint.Their Trip advisor awards for the best hotel in it's class are rightly deserved.

We spent three nights at Shibuya Granbell. The location is fantastic, a short walk from all the Shibuya crossing action, but in a quiet street just far enough away from the noise and neon.. Our room was a decent size with nice furnishings and a great shower. The staff were super helpful, answering enquiries with maps and directions. Would definitely stay there again.

I have spent 10 days here and had very pleasant stay.Hotel was well located - just 5 min walk from underground/train station and Shibuya crossing, but was very quiet.The service was excellent everywhere: at the reception, in the restaurant and including housekeeping.The room ("modern double" type) was not so big but well designed and completely equiped ( TV-Set, telephone, fridge, coffee/tea maker, free mineral water, safe, individual air-condition ).Hotel provided free Wifi.Bathroom also very nice and fully equiped ( soap, shampoo, comb, shaver, hairdryer etc. ).Breakfast was not the same as I 'm used to have in Europe but it was OK. I tried japanese style breakfast and it was the new experience for me, but it was nice.If someone needs more "european" food on breakfast there is another bar/restaurant at the ground floor where small buffet breakfast is served ( scramble eggs, bread, salat, some fruit).Overall hotel was very nice and fullfilled my expectations. I can recommend it to everyone.

We stayed during 3 nights at the hotel. The location, 2 minutes from Shibuya Crossing is just amazing. The hotel was confortable enough and clean. The price was acceptable for the location. The breakfast was below our expectations, but ok, could be worse.

The room I booked here was tiny, but as I soon found out: everything is in Japan! And as as tiny as it was, it had everything you need for a short stay in Tokyo: a comfortable bed, great shower, very clean and even though it is virtually in the heart of Tokyo it was very quiet at night. For a short sightseeing trip, when you are hardly in your room, it is perfect and very close to transport to the rest of the city and the airport. And it looks cool to boot.

Walking to there from the airport shuttle stop is quite tedious because the hotel is on a slope, so make sure you figured out and print out the route before hand or you will be dragging your luggage up and down the hill helplessly like me (esp. when you can't stop and rest on the slope because your luggage will roll down). I like how modern looking the hotel is. There is no problem conversing in English with the counter staff and there are various area maps near the counter as well. The location is pretty ideal (minus the fact dragging luggage up down slope is troublesome) as it is quiet, has convenience store, book store and 100 yen shop within 5 minutes walk, and is less than 10 minutes (of pleasant walk) away from Shibuya Central.Room wise, well we all know how small rooms in tokyo is. The toilet is fairly new and clean so that's a plus point. However I find the carpet floor kind of dusty and it is advisable to wear slippers around. I would definitely encourage anyone considering this hotel to book this.

This is a lovely little hotel right in the midst of everything. Very central and so easy to get around. Fab food nearby with some of the best sushi just across the road, and a yakitori place worth arriving early for so you can get in just opposite. Very clean, good room, lovely staff.

Nice and efficient hotel super close to the main attractions of shibuya. Breakfast included on the price and would definitely advice it for a short staying.Nice restaurants very close with different varieties of food.

Stayed at the Shibuya Granbell hotel for four nights in July 2013.First off, the hotel is not that easy to spot. If you're taking a cab to the hotel, make sure you know the exact address (or even better, the GPS co-ordinates). Check-in was a breeze. The receps speak enough English to get by, but don't expect to conduct extended English conversations with them. The hotel itself looks quite stylish.The room (Small Double) though was tiny. I've stayed in numerous hotels in Tokyo and this must be one of the smaller rooms I've seen. There's space for a double bed (which is very comfortable) and a long narrow desk. It was partly my mistake not to have double-checked the size of the room, but it was overall a very uncomfortable and cramped stay for my partner and me. Otherwise the room wasn't really sound proof, I could hear noise from the Street and music from the room next door.The location is ok, it's not exactly in the heart of Shibuya as it's still a good 5-8 minute walk (over the overhead bridge and through the JR station) to the happening Shibuya areas. But, the Shibuya station itself is an extremely good place from which to explore the rest of Tokyo. The hotel itself is located in what I would term an annex of Shibuya. It's a nice area in itself, lots of eateries (open very late), coffee places, a convenience store and curiously, a concentration of guitar shops.Breakfast--you had a choice of Japanese (fish and rice), Western (scrambled eggs) or French toast. The food is decent.

We stayed at the Granbell for two nights in April. We arrived around lunchtime off the flight from London so it took us a while to find the hotel! It is very conveniently located close to the JR and subway stations and numerous bars and restaurants to suit all budgets. The room was bigger than we were expecting, the breakfast was good (we'd recommend the Japanese style). All the staff were friendly and the was a really good base to acclimatise and check out Tokyo.

The hotel is conveniently located near Shibuya station and the instructions provided on how to get there by foot are perfect once you locate the correct station exit. It is a short walk from the station and easy to do with luggage in tow. Being near Shibuya station puts the hotel in the heart of the very busy and energetic district.An interesting rotating wooden door greets you at the entrance, but once you enter the staff are very friendly and helpful with check-in and I was up in the room in no time. The room was spacious, if a little lacking in storage space. The bathroom area was huge, with separate areas for shower/bath, toilet and sink/vanity mirror taking up about half of the room. The shower featured a rainhead which was a great change from other Tokyo hotels. Unfortunately the large area leads to wasted space and it would have been better used for extra storage or general floor space.The desk area was very small and cluttered with items and hotel amenities, making it not very business work friendly. The room did have a small window, but it looked out into the centre of the hotel along with the windows of other rooms making it rather dark. The bed was large and comfortable and the free internet was also fast and reliable. A small (empty) bar fridge was provided in the room along with communal vending machines. Breakfast is in their bar area and is somewhat limited in selection compared to other Tokyo hotels.The hotel certainly does have its quirks, but if you want to be in the centre of everything, it is a good choice.

Hotel was very easy to find based on the instructions at the website. Friendly reception staff; also a complimentary drink voucher was given.Room was small but that could be expected in Tokyo. It had all the necessities. Really loved spacious shower with very hot water and great water pressure. They are serving breakfast at two different restaurants; loved the cold mashed potatoes and hot sausages at the ground floor and Japanese breakfast in the other restaurant.Wifi was good.

I stayed here in a comfort double for a few days and I enjoyed my stay.The interior was pretty old (Will return but will have modern double), silly things about it annoyed me, the TV was broken and the fridge was empty. However, all the important things- the shower and the bed were fabulous.The best thing about this hotel is the location and the design- the lobby is super cool! The hotel is just around the corner from Shibuya aka the coolest bit of one of the coolest cities in the world. Ideal if you want to stay out all day!Great links to the airport, you can take the N'EX and even if you have massive bags, all the walkways from Shibuya have elevators, so dont worry.Breakfast here is kind of odd, the Japanese version is the best. I find even in the pricey hotels that breakfast is always a little odd. Here you get lettuce with your eggs and bacon. Worth it if you want to be in the centre of everything without spending a ton and you appreciate quirky.

I arrived at the Shibuya Station. I walked about 5-7 minutes to arrive at the hotel. Going a little uphill is okay even pulling my luggage. The staffs are super friendly helpful. Breakfast with western and Japanese styles. The small is compact but full of everything I need. No closet but I didn't need one. I will definitely go back!!!!

The hotel is in a great location, walking distance to many things and an easily accessable train station. There is a fantastic izakaya (neighbourhoodbar) just across the road and up the hill a little that we went two twice.The room was fairly small but this was expected. Staff helpful with out early (and grumpy) arrival and offered umbrellas for the rainy day. No chance of booking in early though- if you'd like a room early perhaps book from the night before which is what I wish we'd done.Breakfast is pretty average

In Tokyo for business and my client recommended this hotel to me.- Amazing location next to Shibuya train station (famous Shibuya street crossing 5 mins walk away)- I arrived at night and it was amazing to see everything lit up. The hotel is one a cute street where there are lots of restaurants nearby.- Checkin was simple. The hallways are dimly lit which I loved as it created a real boutique hotel effect. Even the room was dimly lit which I thought was so nice! - Very cute room. Small but cute. I'm here on business so I have a big suitcase but I was fine living out of my suitcase and working on the bed. No problem.- Shower was good and they give you a sponge too which was convenient as I had forgotten mine :) - Carpet needs a good clean but apart from that the room was fine.- Breakfast : 2 choices. I have only tried the dining room restaurant part and had the western breakfast. Was fine. - Had dinner at the same restaurant too one night and the food was very tasty! Also tried one of the restaurants next to the hotel. Was tasty too! Overall, I would highly recommend this hotel and will be coming back here for work. I don't need a lot of space to work / live...I was out most of the time. So everything was fine for me! Love this place...Love Tokyo!

The hotel is located in a nice quiet part of Shibuya, and is a short walk from Shibuya station (use the pictorial directions on the hotel's website to easily find your way). I stayed in a Modern Double with my husband, and my Tokyo standards the room was relatively spacious. We stayed in the hotel at the start and end of our trip to Japan, so we were able to experience a few different rooms. The first room we stayed in was on Level 6 and had a great view down onto the street below, and the second room we stayed in was on Level 7 and had an even better view - so definitely ask for a high room with a view across Shibuya. We had to book a room for an extra night at the last minute, and while the hotel was able to accommodate us it was located on Level 5, and the room itself felt very narrow and poky. If it had been the first room I stayed in I would have been incredibly disappointed, especially given that the view was of a brick wall. The bathroom facilities in the Level 5 room were also not ideal - the bathroom itself was beautiful and featured a rain shower and bath, however the curtain which separated the bathroom space from the rest of the room was see through and provided little privacy ... not such a problem when you're staying with your partner, but may be an issue when staying with family. While we had breakfast included with our package, I wouldn't recommend bothering with it (at least with the Western style breakfast), as the selection and quality wasn't fantastic. We only tried it the first morning, and then ended up venturing out into Shibuya every other morning.The staff were generally helpful, and it was great being able to store our luggage after checkout and before our flight. The rooms we stayed in were looking a little tired and probably in need of a refresh soon, but the location is a real winner.

I stayed in a single annex room. The room is very small. Carpet was really realy dirty. Bathroom has minimum amenities and bath products. Good point: The bed was comfortable. The lobby has sofas that look so dirty you don't want sit down. The same goes for their bar (or what they call a bar).Breakfast is horrible but free (always the case in Tokyo when it is free).I think that the hotel is used as a love hotel since they have a rest package from 2 to 6 pm. The atmosphere (very dark of the hotel) also confirms this. The only thing that was good was that the staff was very helpful and professional.

I cannot say enough about the Granbell hotel in Shibuya. For those thinking of staying at this establishment I will list out both pros and consPros:2 minute walk from Shibuya train station (west exit)Hotel Staff willing to go the extra mile to serve you with the upmost respect.Rooms are immaculate. (It was noted cleaning staff even lifted the shower drain to clean)Quiet location, yet located 5 minute walk from Shibuya Crossing.The most comfortable bed I have ever experienced in hotel.Cons:Wifi signal fluctuates. Very difficult to surf Internet with this glitch.Highly recommend staying here.

Only 5 mins- walk away from the Shibuya JR stations & all the popular shopping area! My family ( 2 children and my husband) stayed at the Premiere Twin Room for 4 nights and it was such a great stay! The rooms are very neat, clean and someway modern. Its not as fancy as 4 seasons but it surely worth the prices! We got a chance to try the SakuLa restaurant at the hotel last night at our stay because our kids were just tired from the long trip, the restaurant is surprisingly nice with a reasonable price! Recommend!

I stayed for 2 nights in the Comfort room. I arrived about 1.30pm and were unable to check in until 2pm. The staff suggested that I leave my luggage with them and have lunch at Shibuya. The hotel is at a good location with 5 mins walk to Shibuya crossing and JR / Metro. The room size is comfortable and toilet was clean and spacious. As it is near a metro line, I could hear the train when it enters or bypass the station. However it is not that loud that it disturbs me. They have a point system which gives a 50% discount after staying 10 nights with them. Sounds good. Will definitely consider to stay here with a lower budget compared to Cerulean Towers.

We stayed here for altogether 9 days on our roundtrip in Japan . Tokyo was our favoriter and we ended up booking more night here than we had initially. It is so convenient! Close to everything but still a quieter neighbourhood , even though its literally 2 mins from the shibuya station and the great crossing. The hotel itself is very neat and modern . It's true that its a bit scuffed , but I think that's because the rooms are small and you bonk into corners with your bag:) breakfast is satisfying and it's included which is rare in Japan . We loved this place. Check out the little bars and restaurant in the hotel area . They're great . And venture up a bit towards Daikanyama which is more low key but lovely .

Though my friend and I only stayed for 3 nights at the hotel we had amazing service from the Shibuya Granbell team. The hotel's description of how to locate the hotel from JR Shibuya Station was great!! We chose the single rooms each and was very satisfied. Our rooms were so immaculately clean, spacious for what we were expecting and amazingly comfortable beds. The bathroom was great with the hand held shower heads as well as the rain shower available, our favourite Toto toilets were available, And daily room maintenance was available too. I stayed in room 701 where as you walk in the bed is to your right, the desk to your left and straight ahead where the window is is your bathroom. Therefore I found that my room was very quiet. However, my friend had room 702 where as you walk in the bathroom was to your left then desk to left and bed at end where window was. She found her room to be a bit more noisy but when you're on holiday, staying in Shibuya for 3 nights a little noise doesn't bother you. The reception team were great!! Helped us out on several occasions of how to get to places, was very helpful with our 3am taxi to Tsukiji market, and overall very pleasant from check-in to check-out. Would definitely stay there again!! Thank you Shibuya Granbell team, we loved our stay with you!!!

We spent 3 nights while visiting Tokyo. The hotel is perfectly located, 5 minutes walking from Shibuya main shopping area, undreground station and the famous crossing. It is situated in a quiet area with plenty of small restaurants / bars around. The bedroom is quite good in size, comfortable bed, the bathroom is well equipped and very clean, there is a safe and air conditioning, and quite enough room to put your stuff. Breakfast is ok on the ground floor, although I would advise you to go on the 2nd floor restaurant where you have more choice and a better service. They offered us a welcoming drink at their bar because we booked directly on their website, nice attention! The staff is helpful and speak good English. Wi-fi is available everywhere, there is also a computer and a printer at the reception, useful to print out boarding passes. I will definetely come back for a next stay.

This is a Japanese "business hotel" so I didn't have high expectations for my stay at Granbell. I checked in really late at night, close to midnight and the process was a breeze. I actually arrived in Tokyo a few days before checking-in, and I left my huge suitcase with them. When I was checking-in, the front desk mentioned that the suitcase was already in my room. It was such a thoughtful gesture.I will admit that the room can do with a bit more work - it looks a little tired and worn down. There was also a funny smell from the toilet but I couldn't work it out what it was. That said, the toilet was very clean and well-maintained. Not much space to put your own toiletries though. Water pressure is great. There was the standard Japanese toilet which keeps the seat warm (don't be alarmed when you sit on it!).The room is tiny but again I was expecting that, so it wasn't a deal-breaker for me. There is a small desk just enough to put your mobile phone and wallet.The bed is comfortable. Room was quiet and the A/C worked well. There is also a dehumidifier but I did not turn it on.I had the Japanese breakfast which was yummy. Grilled mackeral, rice, miso soup, natto. Breakfast of champions (and heart-friendly too).Location - this is where Granbell really shines. It's less than a 2-minute walk to the 24-hours supermart where you can buy snacks and onigiri (rice balls). 5-minute walk to Shibuya station. It is initially a little overwhelming with the overhead pedestrain crossings but you will figure it out very quickly. Plenty of sign posts to mark the way. The front desk is also very helpful; they can provide a map and directions. The hotel is also about a 5 minute walk to Ramen Nagi, a great place for a quick bowl of hot ramen. Plenty of other ramen shops around too.I stayed in a single room. If I'm back in Tokyo for a short stay I will stay here again. Can't beat the price and the location!

The Shibuya Granbell hotel is a pretentious “boutique” hotel which is well past its design sell by date. We should have realised this from the lobby which, when we found it, was scruffy, with grubby, grey, sagging sofas and a wooden floor which looked as if it had never been washed or polished. Whilst the location was great, it was no better than the other hotels we had stayed at in the Shibuya area on our two previous visits. Our “Premier Double” was simply awful. The room was on the third floor, looking out on to a tiled wall. To say the room was tired is an understatement: the wall paper was peeling; the veneer was falling off the bedside table and secured with sellotape; it was impossible to get into the far side of the bed without clambering over it (makes you wonder what a ‘small double’ would be like); the glass surface of the main table was so chipped, my husband cut his thumb; the ‘runner’ over the bed was stained; the toilet was dirty and the sink became completely blocked. The room would not be suitable for anyone one with a disability since it had a high step up to the bathroom and toilet area. The disappointment with the room was matched by the equally appalling breakfast: cold scrambled eggs, if you were lucky, some squash masquerading as fruit juice, lukewarm tea and coffee and a few soggy salads. We did not try the Japanese breakfast. In fairness, staff were helpful when we complained and our complaints were dealt with promptly, but their English was not as good as I had encountered elsewhere. The bed was very comfortable and bathroom itself, lovely. However, none of this alleviated our feeling that we were paying over the odds for an overhyped hotel which provided accommodation and food of a very poor quality compared to other hotels in the area. Go somewhere else!

This hotel is less than 5 min by walk of Shibuya Station in a very quiet street.It means you have direct access to Narita airport via the NEX and an easy access to the subway network. Very usefull in that city. No need to speak about Shibuya by itself. A mustThis is a boutique hotel. Its design is dark (especially the elevators) but very nice. Carpets must be change in my room. Too old.Wifi was working correctly but no international channels on TV.Breakfasts were average in both restaurants. Not a lot of quantity, no variety but good quality.At last, the staff was very friendly and helpfull.

this is a nice hotel, well located in the Shibuya area in Tokyo. Small, but reasonably priced.The single rooms are really tiny! So better ask for a double room. But the rooms are clean and the bathroom is very comfortable. When we arrived at the hotel around 13H30, rooms were not ready and many other guests were waiting for their rooms and complaining about it. We had to wait till 14H00 before we could enter our rooms. This was not so nice, if you just had a long trip.Breakfast is also not so great.But overall i would certainly recommand this hotel.

Finding a hotel in Tokyo is not always so easy. The city is huge and accomodation doesn't always come cheap. After scanning dozens of options, my wife and I decided to stay at Granbell Hotel Shibuya for a week in April 2013. And we were very happy with our choice. The location is excellent. Its very close to the Shibuya metro and train station thus making it very easy to travel around Tokyo as well as to and from Narita Airport. Its also at the quiet end of Shibuya, which means that all the sights and shopping in Shibuya are within convenient walking distance but yet the hotel is in a very quiet area. We slept with our window open for most of the week (would never work in eg. NYC) and we were never woken once due to street noise. Our room was a modern double. And as with most hotel rooms in Tokyo, the room wasn't huge but big enough for two people and very clean. The only downside to the hotel (as with many other Japanese hotels) was the western style breakfast which wasn't fantastic and quite small in its portions. But on the other hand, there is a french bakery and a Starbucks on the 4th floor in Mark One Plaza across the street from the Shibuya station in case one would like a more hearty breakfast. And considering the price we paid for our room, we are in no position to take down the overall grade due to the breakfast (wich was edible but not fantastic). So overall, a great and very affordable option that I could highly recommend.

The boutique concept is appealing, in principle: rainshower head, designer room, fabulous bed. The room (superior double) wasn't even a bad size for Tokyo. Unfortunately, it feels as though the person who designed the concept isn't the same person who's maintaining the place: the room needs painting, the elevators and hallways need a good vaccuum and some Windex. And avoid the dubious buffet breakfast in the bar out front: go straight to the restaurant on the 2nd floor which is partly buffet & partly menu service: at least it looks clean and the food isn't sitting out all morning. The Japanese breakfast is healthy and tasty and the french toast isn't too bad. Overall, the food's not great (but at least it saves you some cash in a pricey city.) However the rooms seem well sound-insulated, great for sleeping, and although you have to negociate several flights of stairs of pedestrian overpass to get to and from Chibuya station (so pack light!) it's really close and Chibuya is handy to great eating areas like Naka-Meguro, Ebisu, Shinjuku, Roppongi (by bus) as well as destinations West of central Tokyo (Chuo line, mount Fuji etc.).

The Shibuya Granbell Hotel is the perfect place to stay in Tokyo. I love the Shibuya neighbourhood and this was in a quiet corner that is easy to get to, but not totally in the middle of all the crazy. What I loved about this hotel is the rooms are fairly small, but absolutely perfectly formed. The bed is super comfy, I loved the funky hip hotel design and the bath and shower area was extensive. The bath's also very deep. The staff are extremely friendly. For example, when we were leaving, it was pouring with rain and they gave us umbrellas to take away. The breakfast is great too - I would urge you to go for the traditional Japanese breakfast, which is delicious there. There is free wifi, but it really only works in reception. The cosmetic products are great too. I really have no faults with this hotel. At the end of our Japan trip, we stayed in a different area and hotel, and we really missed our Shibuya Granbell experience. The second hotel we stayed in was in Shinjuku, which is great, but very loud and crazy. Shibuya was my preferred of the two neighbourhoods - plus it's easy to get to from the airport. Pluses all around!
user_name:
Nyclondoner
New York City, New York

review_body: I have been to Tokyo many times and usually stay around the Shinjuku area. This time, I wanted to be even closer to the action and decided on Shibuya Granbell Hotel. I was just expecting a place to keep my bags (and shopping!) and for somewhere to sleep. But this hotel turned out to me so much more - it felt like a cool boutique hotel in the middle of the city with everything I needed for my stay. What I loved: The location - less than 5 minutes walk from Shibuya station in a nice little area of Shibuya. The staff - it was raining one day and they offered us free umbrellas, we were able to store my bike with no issue. The bathroom is an excellent size and the rainwater shower head was awesome. The bed was comfortable and it was great to be able to open the window to get fresh air into the room. Complimentary bottled water daily and a daily breakfast to get you started.What I didn't love: Not much really. I mean the room was small, but that was to be expected with budget Tokyo hotels. It would be great if they had some more shelf space on the walls to put some clothes.I would stay here again for sure!

We stayed here at the end of March and loved the hotel, it has a very modern Japanese feel. Great bathroom with all mod cons. Its in a great location, walk to Shibuya station and JR station, shopping and we even walked to Meiji Shrine and Harajuku. The staff were very helpful in explaining the subway maps and neighbourhoods to help us get around. There is a great little restaurant / bar at the front of the hotel to have a casual breakfast and in the evening (in typical Japanese efficiency of space style) it becomes a pizza bar with cool music for hanging out and having a drink, I recommend the chicken teriyaki pizza if you want a change from "real" Japanese food!

We stayed at the Shibuya Granbell Hotel at the end of our Japan trip in Jan this year, and we arrived to the biggest blizzard Tokyo had seen in at least 10 years. So THANK GOD the hotel was close to the station. One of the ladies from the hotel came out and tried to help us drag our bags through the snow, which was lovely because the weather was dreadful!The rooms were pretty decent. I read that they would be small but I found them to be adequate, we didn't spend a lot of time in the room. The lighting was very dim, which was irritating when trying to get ready. Wifi is available free with a deposit from the front desk and the showers were hot, what more can you want?The breakfast HOWEVER was so so so so god awful. There is a choice of 2 places (fancy right? WRONG!) We tried both, after the first was mostly inedible we thought it couldnt get any worse. Wrong again. The downstairs one was stone cold, and they didnt even both to try to keep the food warm - the scrambled eggs were in a fruit bowl? You honestly couldn't pay me to eat at those places again.So, location - fantastic, room - clean, warm, cozy food - dont even waste your time and stomach space

stayed here in 2009 and 2012.....about 10 min walk from train station.staff were really friendly and helpfull to me...lovely room,no great view but cosy bed.internet connection.japanese style toilet with buttons to scoosh your bum clean,loved watching the sumo wrestling and local japanese news all the time,also a great wee bar and restaurant area were we got free uk style breakfast...defo stay again

We stayed 2 nights @ Granbell, it's a great location and walking distance to shibuya subway or JR station. The room is very small however most of the hotel room in Tokyo is small anyway. The staffs are friendly and very helpful. The entrance of the hotel doesn't look like a hotel more like an apartment but it's worth every money we spent.

You may have heard that the boutique hotel concept has inexplicably barely caught on in Japan and its true. This is one of the only such hotels in Tokyo. It is well located just a quick walk from the shibuya station and this is very nice as you'll likely be dragging luggage (i had skis too) which is no mean feat in one of the busiest pedestrians areas in the world. make sure you study the hotels map on its website for the walking directions. If followed to a T the will get you there in about 5 minutes. However, there are numerous ways to blow it and its a hilly area so when in doubt, consult the map.The hotel itself is nicely designed. Very modern and very functional. My room, as you can see, was in total (including the bathroom) approximately 10' x 6'. This meant there was practically no room to walk around; however, it was totally comfortable, bright (as it had two huge opening windows) and very functional. The bathroom was a glass enclosed unit with a fancy Japanese toilet and an awesome scaldingly hot rain bath type shower, which was much appreciated given the freezing cold tokyo winter. The location is great: it's just far enough from shibuya crossing so as to be quiet but close enough to walk there in five minutes. This also means its only a fifteen minute walk from harajuku and ayoma, putting you right in the middle of some of tokyos coolest neighborhoods. If you're here in part at least to shop you really can't be better situated than here as every major label and department store in the city has a branch no further than 20 minutes walk away. In Tokyo this means that every brand you've ever heard of and thousands you haven't are at your doorstep, without the need to get on the train. A big plus in this mega city. Being close to shibuya station also means you can pick up the JR Narita express right there, which is the best way to get back to the airport from the city unless a $300 taxi ride is in your budget. On the downside the hotel shows its age almost everywhere. A new coat of paint on the interior walls of the lobby and the rooms would do wonders to cover up all the scuff marks that come with wear and tear. Some linens were torn and the bar downstairs looks like it was once hip but has since been taken over by football fans who've tacked beer posters everywhere. The restaurant definitely leaves something to be desired so don't go thinking the free breakfast is a selling point as its nothing at all. However, it really doesn't matter given that there are a million options nearby where you can have anything from the best French pastries east of Paris to donuts from New York's Donut Plant (at the only outlet of that Mecca for fried dough outside of the lower east side I know of in the world). In summary I'd stay here again in a minute. With its convenience and comfort and the fact that you can actually get a nice and very stylish room with your own bathroom in the middle of Tokyo for about $100 (try finding that in New York or London) you can't beat the shibuya grandbell.

I only spent a short time at Shibuya Granbell, arriving at 1am for a 1 night stay between flights. The room was small and basic, which is standard for Tokyo, and fine as I was on my own and it was just for 1 night, but I don't think I would have been comfortable in such a small space for a long period of time. However the hotel was in a fantastically convenient location right near Shibuya train station. The staff were pleasant and helpful and the hotel was clean and stylish. The spa package provided had some lovely products. My only major complaint is that there was no wi-fi (or if there was I couldn't find any info on how to connect to it). There was a LAN connection but as I only had my iphone I would have liked to be able to connect to wi-fi

Just back from a stint in Tokyo. We stayed in the Granbell for 3 nights. The hotel has a great location with a lovely restaurant just up the road. The rooms are small but perfectly laid out with everything you need including a wonderfull powerful shower. it is spotlessly clean & comfortable & very quiet considering its location. The staff are very friendly & serve a decent breakfast. It boasts free WiFi throughout the hotel. its a five minute walk to the busiest pedestrian crossing in the world & the Shibuya train station. I would stay there again should i ever return to Tokyo. Hai!

Room size is tiny, but if you don't have much luggage its the perfect amount a solo/business traveler needs. Stayed in the smallest room they offer (I think 12.6m). Breakfast at the Japanese style restaurant was surprisingly well presented and was a good way to kick off the day. Best part is access to Shibuya.

Location in the middle of Shibuya a hundred meters away from train station is hard to beat. The rooms in the Annex are generally nicer and newer than the ones in the older part of the hotel. Avoid the long, narrow and dark 'premier double' rooms. The 'modern double' rooms are far better. The lobby of the hotel is cluttered with bags and posters and is showing significant wear and tear. Some of the staff is quite unfriendly - particularly odd in Japan. Breakfast is fine.

We got lost the first time we headed for this hotel. we saluted their generosity and hospitality for keeping our luggages on our behalf whilst we went for a short trip out of Tokyo city. Hence, our expectation of their service had been topped since. On the day of for us to check in, I personally asked them whether it was okay for them to give us a lift for our many huge luggages. Frankly, despite us being a bunch of ladies, my friends and i were considered quite independent in terms of minding our own stuffs especially when we were in overseas. We will not trouble others if we were capable of doing ourselves. In that case, we had just came back from a whole day of walking around and each of us lugging at least 3KG of baggage. Hence, their little help will really make our day. Mind you, we were not mind of tipping if they kindly send our luggage to our rooms (FYI, there was luggage trolley in the lobby).We were so shocked when they refused to help us. It wasn't they did not understand what we were requesting because I had explained in understandable universal gestures and known English. Their English level was clearly good given the fact they fully understood my other questions especially on paid services (eg. International calls).I mean, wasn't hospitality all about providing your customers' needs and requests? We were even surprised with the fact that they were awarded the Best Hotel by Tripadvisor. In fact, the main reason my friends and I decided to book this hotel was because if that reason. Clearly, we had been disappointed when we had not even stepped into our rooms yet. Generally, the rooms were considered fine given the price we paid. But the cleanliness was unacceptable. Spider cobwebs and dust were concealed. Well, obviously they weren't well hidden. The bathrooms were truthfully barely covered. I couldn't justify the reason behind their "creativity" of exposing the bathrooms. I believe this hotel wasn't labeled as "love" hotels by the reviewer, was it?Location wise, I would say it is centrally situated in Shibuya. Tokio Mall was merely opposite the road. Nearest subway was also a few minutes walk. I must say, be prepared for a sloppy hike. The next time I visit Tokyo, I would apparently choose other hotel.

Booked this hotel for three nights after reading reviews on Trip advisor and it didnt disappoint. It is only a five minute walk from Shibuya station (south exit, west gate) I got the directions from the hotel web site and it was easy to find, tucked away behind a big wooden door in a quiet area. We were early so left our bags and went out for the day. When we arrived back our bags had been taken to our room and we were also upgraded from a deluxe king to a cosy suite. It is quite a quirky hotel. We opened the door to our room to a spiral staircase that you walked up to get to the room. It was very nice. A small lounge and coffee table with a flat screen TV, a nespresso pod coffee machine, fridge, free wifi accessable from the room, a large king size bed, a big bath on a level above the bed(separated by a sliding screen),good storage space for bags and clothes and the best toilet that was so automatic it washed and dried! The toiletries were amazing. Everything was fresh and clean.The towels were changed and bed made every day. Breakfast was included and we only went to thr restaurant on the 2nd floor. Tried the different types breakfasts and found the french one to be the best for us. There were tourist pamphlets in the lobby but got most of our information from the tourist office at the station. Hotel is close to Shibuya Crossing, many restaurants and shops. It was value for money as I had a friend staying at the Cerulean Hotel up the road and he complained that he had to pay for so many things that wernt included in the nightly tarrif e.g internet, breakfast, after 7pm if you are drinking in the bar on the top floor you have to pay 500y per person for the privilege even if you are a hotel guest! I would definately stay here again

We stayed here for 3 nights at the end of a 3 week holiday around Japan. Chose it for its TA reviews and proximity to Shibuya. We weren't disappointed. The hotel has a funky and boutique feel. It is small but has good facilities. It's looking a bit tired, it probably needs a refresh, but the room we had was a good size for Japan with a separate toilet and spacious shower room with a nice overhead shower and a bath. The bed was king size and comfortable. There was a small lounge suite in the room also. We paid about AUD190 per night via Japanican. Given the size of the room, the standard and the location we felt this was good value for money. The rate included breakfast for the two of us. The staff were very helpful. Shibuya is a great area with good access to other parts of Tokyo via JR and Metro rail lines. It is only one stop or a comfortable stroll from Harajuku which is another very interesting and fun area to explore. No hesitation in recommending Shibuya Granbell Hotel.

I stayed here for two nights before leaving Tokyo and it was initially quite a shock to see the tiny single room - the smallest I'd ever stayed in - but it was a great deal and just fine for the short stay. I might have felt differently if the weather was poor and had to stay inside, but that was not the case. The small hotel has two entrances and is easy to find, a few minutes walk from the Shibuya police station and a very large luxury hotel - The Cerulean Tower - which is handy because the express bus to and from Narita stops there. The room included breakfast which was more like brunch food. The in-house restaurant makes excellent pizza. There are tons of great restaurants in the area and Shibuya itself is a great place to hang for a few days - lots of really interesting shops and great people watching. Close to the subway and parks, and an easy walk to other neighbourhoods. The staff were very good, and helpful with directions. There's an excellent self-laundry about a five-minute walk from the hotel that's easy to use...just bring change. My only complaint is that the free wi-fi was limited to the lobby. It would have been nice to have it in the rooms.

We booked this hotel based on recommendations on Trip Advisor, Lonely Planet and a few design guides. I have no idea how this hotel gets the ratings it does. We checked in to a deluxe room and were shocked at how dirty it was. The linen/towels were fine but everything else was filthy. The bathroom was full of hairs, mold, small pieces of rubbish. The main living area had a moldy ceiling, marks all over the walls, dust/grime on all surfaces, moldy coffee machine, junk in wardrobe. We complained and they moved us to a suite with the spiral stair case. Its obviously fabulous in terms of design, but was equally dirty and so run down. There was what looked like coke sprays on the columns, mold on all the curtains, disgusting bathroom. Hotel lift was the same - filthy carpet, greasy marks, hairs stuck in joinery!? So even though it was a huge upgrade we just couldn't tolerate it and left. The girls at the desk were very helpful and happily refunded our prepayment - so the service in that sense was good. This hotel was totally at odds with our normal experience of Japan where everything is so clean and well looked after, even the smallest and cheapest hotels. We ended up checking into the Cerulean Towers as it was so close and had availability. It was a boring 5* business hotel, but we so appreciated the comfortable and clean rooms after such a disappointment!

This hotel is a great find - if not slightly tricky to find for the weary traveller negotiating their way across Shibuya. Actually, if you take the Airport Limousine the hotel is actually closer to the Cerulean Tower Tokyo Hotel stop than the Shibuya Mark City Building. And like everywhere in Japan - look up! While the entrance is sort of discreet the name of the hotel is clearly displayed on the side of the building.I stayed in an Annex single which is amply big enough for 1 person. There's not a lot of standing room but the bed is a big double and very comfortable and the bathroom is a great size with one of the best showers I've every had. And if you feel a bit modest about the see through walls in the bathroom you can always pull the curtains.My friends (with one child) stayed in a premier twin room which was also a good sized room for the price.The location is excellent with lots of great restaurants nearby and you are only a 5 min walk from Shibuya station which has access to most train lines in Tokyo.Some people may not like the slightly dark interior of the hallways which makes it feel like a nightclub but I think it has been done really tastefully and gives it a certain 'edgy' style.Staff also really helpful with adequate english.Would definitely stay there again - now that I know where it is!

Me & my husband booked 2 nights, to be paid once we go to the hotel. However we couldn't come back to Shibuya on the 1st night as we were stuck in Hiroshima that evening ( we didn't know that trains don't run from Hiroshima-Tokyo the whole night) We were sad because we thought we still had to pay for the 1st night because it was a very short notice cancellation that we made around 8.00 pm that night. But when we explained it over the phone, the staff very politely said that they will not take money from us for the 1st night, which was so nice (irrespective of their policy where they can charge some amount for short notice cancellation) We were extremely happy & surprised to see how good they were where as in most of the other countries it's only about making money. I think this is exactly what a tourist/traveler wants in a hotel because you never know when you are going to miss transport/when you are unable to stay the night at the hotel for an unforeseen reason.Also the staff gave us a lot of information/directions on where to go, allowed us to keep our luggage as much as we want before checked in/after checked out. There were English speaking staff as well.Hotel is situated in a good spot which is walking distance to all big shopping centres and had access to public transport. Hotel rooms looked very nice too, clean, nicely decorated, comfortable beds. Breaky we had at their restaurant was yummy as well. Overall we had a comfortable night (free from cigarette smoke smell like in most of the other hotels in Japan even though it said non smoking)

Booked a Premier Double Room for 2 people.The biggest plus for the hotel is the location in Shibuya. A five to six minute walk to the Shibuya JR Line entrance, an additional minute to three for the different subway line entrances and to Shibuya crossing. Restaurants and convenience and drug stores within a 1-2 block radius of the hotel for ease, or all you have to do is walk to the main Shibuya area. The room itself was not good, ceiling had mold/mildew on it. Staff cleaned it with some disinfectant when I went down to explain the problem.Room is small, as advertised, but for the price and location, is what you could expect. Would be a good hotel if you're just looking for a launching off point and don't plan to be in the room except to sleep. Free wi fi is in the lobby.
user_name:
Daikan21
New York City, New York

review_body: The Granbell hotel is great for budget travelers to Tokyo. The staff is great and helpful and everything worked fine (elevators, internet, etc). The room was tiny, but of course, everything is tiny in Tokyo unless you pay a great amount of money.Location is fantastic, 3 blocks away from Shibuya station, meaning that you'll access almost everything with just one train.Tip: Getting to the hotel is kind of tricky from Shibuya, use the map they provide on their website and look for the little bar in street, then look towards the iiner part of the block and you'll see the big brown door.

The room, especially the bathroom, was dirty, (loose hairs of all types and a discarded contact among other things) and the ceiling was covered with black mildew. We were very disappointed. The place is also crawling with foreigners, and the direct environs of the hotel seedy -- perhaps appropriate because it advertises itself proudly as a "day-use" hotel. Yes, it's very close to Shibuya station, and the wait staff at the breakfast restaurant on the second floor were extremely nice. But not a great place for families. The vibe was funky, but we suspected the dramatic low-lighting in the hallways was to cover up dirt.

My 2nd time staying at the Granbell Hotel in Shibuya. Stayed there 2 years ago and really enjoyed it. The compact rooms are great. it's an excellent value, we located (close to Shibuya Station). staff is accommodating and friendly. the surprise this time was the food in the front restaurant. excellent food and service. no wifi in the rooms, but you can get a wireless router at the front desk for a small deposit. Worth a stay. As stated: great value and excellent location.

I stayed for business for 6 nights in October 2012.Rooms are small but the space is really maximised and they have a cool design.The breakfast choice is limited and ok if you are staying there for a couple of nights as we were staying longer we ate outside a couple of times at breakfast.There is no wifi in the room unless you borrow a router - I didn't realise this until the last night as the receptionist didn't speak very good english when we checked in so didn't know this facility was available. Best to take advantage of the wifi as there is hardly any free wifi in the city (I expected there to be much more free wifi in cafes etc but there isn't).Short walk to Shibuya station and to shops etc so really good location.I have stayed in nicer Tokyo hotels but this is good for the money.

Me and my wife were just staying here for a night before heading home, therefore we didn't ask for any upgrade or anything. First of all, this hotel is super hard to find and it is kind of up the slope, but other that, I'd totally consider this hotel again. The room is small, but understandable because this is Tokyo, for the price we paid, I think it is decent. In addition, there is a free breakfast which I don't normally see this being offer in many hotel in Tokyo. This hotel has very modern design and most important of all, the location, you can easily walk to anywhere within minutes. The staffs are friendly and service is good.

First, positives: - Location, location, location. This place is a 2-minute walk from Shibuya station, which is one of the major train/subway stations in Tokyo and therefore makes it convenient to get almost anywhere in the city. Shibuya is also one of the centers of youth culture in the city, so it's more vibrant and fun (though also therefore more crowded and a tad grimier, which I actually kind of liked) than other neighborhoods.- Room design: Our "Modern double" room was small but comfy and ingeniously laid out, as many Japanese hotel rooms are. Special props for the bathroom, which is glassed in on two sides so you can peer into it from the bedroom portion of the room (curtains provided for privacy). It creates a sense of a larger space -- not claustrophobic at all. It was totally clean.- Price: though it was among the more expensive hotels in our two week trip through Japan, it's a good value for this area.Now, the downsides.- Firstly, and this is not something I'd typically say of many small foreign hotels, they really need to have staff who speak better English. Why? Because this hotel now has a Tripadvisor award, and they are *clearly* trying to cater to and solicit foreign business -- the majority of guests we saw in the hotel were *not* Japanese. The staff is ever-friendly and polite, as were almost all folks we met in Japan, but they didn't quite have the language skills to really provide good concierge service (booking restaurants, providing directions, etc) or to explain many intricacies of the hotel. Speaking of which:- There is no service elevator in this tallish hotel. That means for several hours during the middle of the day, when the staff clean the rooms, the two elevators were constantly in use by staff. This meant to get up to -- and down from -- our room in the afternoon, we often ended up stopping at every floor so service people could get on and off the elevator to do their work. What should have been quick stops to grab something from our room became frequent fifteen-minute wastes of time. Why didn't we just use the stairs? Because...- The stairway doors are locked. Maybe there's a way for guests to open them, but I certainly couldn't figure it out. Maybe they open automatically in case of emergency, but in addition to being an annoyance I did worry about safety in the event of fire or something.- The bedroom windows can only be opened and closed by staff with a special key. This isn't atypical of hotels, and usually it's not a problem because there's climate control in the room to adjust for heat or cold. EXCEPT...- We stayed during the week when the month changed from October to November. And it turns out that starting November 1st, the hotel turns on the heat, and doesn't allow you to use the controls in the room to cool things down. So we were stuck in a warmish room, unable to turn on the AC, or to open the window without calling a service person to do it for us. Majorly annoying, especially after two people take showers and the room gets so humid the window actually fogs up.I'm a little sad to point out these flaws, because again, the staff was super friendly, the room was neat and we enjoyed our stay in the area. But I feel like the Granbell now has an international rep and they could do a bit more to live up to it.

Was recommended to go to this area and after reading other comments on trip advisor found the Hotel easily. Thanks to others as it is a small entrance. Found the staff very helpful and frendily ESP when it came to organizing our own day trips. Wireless Internet in room, thanks again to trip advisor, ask reception and pay a 1000yen bond. Rooms are average for Japan but lovely big bathroom and still enjoying the Japanese toilets (bidets). My partner and I stayed here 3nights and after the first breakfast in the downstairs resturaunt was cold toast and eggs we tried the upstairs the next morning and found it much better, at least hot and fresh. Loving Japan and still here have made our way down the Islands after 2weeks, off in a few days. Highly recommend the JR rail pass and you need to arrange before you leave home. Awesome Counrty clean and people very frendily.

Great hotel. For a very reasonnable price, you get a nice, clean and modern hotel in Shibuya, 3 mins from the Shibuya Station, which links 3 metro lines and 1 JR line. So going wherever you go is quite straightforward. You get a discounted rate is you stay more than 5 days I think.Rooms are small, yes, but well designed. I never went back to my room before 9pm anyway, so I did not really matter for me. Shower is powerful and enjoyable. I slept well, AC works very well, the room was dark at night without much exterior noise.The staff was helpful. They have wi-fi in rooms and it was efficient, and free breakfast, which is ok, no more, no less, it kind of fills you up until lunch. Overall, I recommend this place to everyone who would like to stay in this area. I give this hotel a 5 star rating because I had great and efficient email communications with them before my arrival and it was everything as advertized. Also, I thought I would have to pay big bucks to stay in Tokyo and I was really not the case ( paid 120$ all taxes included for a single. Doubles are a bit higher).

My husband and I stayed here after finding a great deal online. We easily found the hotel by following their instructions on their website and was amazed at how close it was to the station. We stayed in one of the annex rooms and found it to be of a sufficient size (not huge, but comfortable). The bathroom was definitely a highlight with the lovely rain showerhead and excellent water pressure. Breakfast was included and they offered a choice between 2 restaurants, we only went to the level 2 one so can't comment on the other one. The food was ok not amazing, but with so much great food choice around Tokyo, this didn't matter so much to us. Overall, would probably stay here again if another deal came up.

Stayed at the Shibuya Granbell Hotel for 3 nights. Location couldn't be any better for access to the train station, Shibuya Crossing (the busiest intersection in the world, it's quite an experience), shopping, a huge park and the Harajuku shopping district. It's a 3-5 min walk to the Hachiko entrance (yes, just like the dog from the Richard Gere movie, the statue of the dog is there), which is also where the Shibuya Crossing is located - if you're unsure, just wait for a light change and watch the masses, and I do mean MASSES, cross in every direction (there is a Starbucks that over looks the location from one story above. Buy a coffee and have a seat at the windows). The hotel staff are exceptional, incredibly friendly and helpful (even planning trips, recommendations, etc.). The room cleaning was always amazing and I don't thinkin ever saw the cleaning staff (ALWAYS see the in the hotels in the states, no matter what time you arrive/depart), but the room look exceptionally clean and organized no matter how much we messed it up from the previous day. The bed was very comfortable, fairly firm but not too much. I never heard any street noise, either. The "robotic" toilet is quite the experience: heated seat (and you can adjust the heat), several bidet options - normally I would explain that, but I'm just going to let you figure that one out on your own - keeps it exciting for you, haha. It'll be one of those, "Hey sweetheart, check this out..." moments. Think we had a Premier Double room which was more than big enough, but keep in mind this is Tokyo, nothing is really "big"...except the prices :-)I would whole-heartedly recommend this hotel.Only con's would be no wifi in the room, have to go to lobby for that. I remedied the wifi issue for the entire trip by renting a mobile wifi device from www.globaladvancedcomm.com which I both my wife and I can connect our iPads at the same time. Speed was pretty and convenience even better. Cost is about 930 Yen a day, which is approx $12 USD, based on 80:1 Yen:USD conversion at the time of this writing. You can arrange to have it delivered to the airport or hotel for your pick-up. They request 2 day advance notice to get it to your location, but I did mine last minute and they delivered to my hotel room the next day by 11am, outstanding! They even include a pre-paid envelope to return the device when done.

Hotel is very clean and well managed. So, good choice to stay here.But be careful of the restaurants.Breakfast in Restaurant on 2nd floor is worse - dont try itBreakfast downstairs is simple but okBe careful of the staff in the downstair restaurant, from time to time the charge you 1.500 yen as a "tablecharge" even when you are staying in the hotel and they refused to give it back.The pizza is also not good - so avoid both restaurants.

I was staying there for a long weekend trip tagging along my boyfriend's biz trip back in end Jun 2012 and was quite disappointed with this hotel, except for the fact that it's conveniently located close enough to the heart of Shibuya and the stations.I've been to Tokyo quite a no. of times and are aware that rooms are normally quite small but in general, service should top as part of the Japanese culture - but I was rather disappointed with Granbell in terms of service, their offering and things worsen with communications problem of the staff.- the staff put us in a room with 2 single beds when my boyfriend specifically requested for a double room, for him + girlfriend, after his biz portion of the trip and the staff happily confirmed of the double room. thought it was only a miscomm. and asked the staff to change it to one with a double bed, but the only one available was a suite hence will cost even more. (we've already paid more to change from the single room, to a "double room" after the biz trip). so we decided to ask them to help move the 2 single beds side by side and the staff told us it could not be done (honestly, as hotelier, would you really put couples in 2 single beds?)... when I was about to complain and asked to speak to the manager, I had to repeat myself 3 - 4 times to different staff as no one seemed to be able to speak proper English and in the end, nothing was done except "we are sorry"  - wi-fi was not available in the room but the lobby only, not even if you offer to pay (don't understand how it could be a biz hotel)  given the price range, there are a lot of better hotels in Shibuya (be it service, rooms) and I would not recommend staying there.

Due to its close proximity to Shibuya Station, there are many subway lines as well as trains that take you to and from Shibuya, including the Narita Express. The hotel is small and unassuming but the huge wooden door at the entrance is impressive. The lobby is tiny and there, they have wifi available. The hallway decor is dark with black walls and carpet (similar to waiting for Space Mountain ride at Disneyland), but the rooms are small and bright. For the size of the room, the glass enclosed bathroom takes up at least 25% of the space. The bed was comfortable and all the amenities were available (except for in-room wifi). Lan cable was available for laptops. The rooms are soundproof as we didn't hear traffic from the streets or any of our neighbors. There are some stains on the carpet, but the room is overall clean. If they replace the carpeting with wood or vinyl flooring which looks like wood, the rooms would appear new. The Japanese breakfast on the 2nd floor was just OK and the western breakfast was not very good. That would be my only complaint. Otherwise, I would highly recommend this hotel if you can get a good rate on a third party booking engine (ie, booking.com).

We stayed in a large single which has a semi double bed (only avail on Japanese booking site of theirs as it is a bed just 20cm less wide than a double/full size bed). It was enough for the 4 days we were there.Pros- free breakfast at one of their 2 restaurants (get the Japanese option at the 2nd floor restaurant ), great location on the west side of shibuya, close to train, modern (even if it's a tad worn), super helpful staff (all fluent in English), wifi in lobby, cabled net in rooms, large bathroom.Cons: couldn't open the bathroom window so we had to rely on aircon the whole time for air, push button rain shower didn't seem to 'hold' (the shower was on the handheld was good though), wifi in lobby (hotel like this should have wifi all over), sound travelled through the glass doors/wall so lack of bathroom privacy (even if there was a curtain).I would say there are similar hotels with modern rooms in Tokyo so if you are going for design then you should probable pick some other hotel but for the location, price and value the Granbell is hard to beat. There aren't as many other options this side of Shibuya in this price point.

I stayed here for a business trip as i wanted to be close to the action but still have a nice hotel (on the company of course!). I booked a month in advance for 11 nights and my room dropped from 26k to 12k a night. The rooms are large for tokyo (i have been told) and there is a decent bar and restuarant downstairs that is cheap for hotel standards.I think the best part is the location, super close to the station and in walking distance of the 2 best clubs in tokyo - Womb and Unit. I will be staying here everytime i come to tokyo from now on

I just stayed at the Granbell and found the location to the Shibuya station and shopping district extremely convenient. The breakfast was handy. The rooms were very clean and cozy and quiet. I stayed in a single and it was very comfortable. Travelling solo I found this hotel to be a great little gem in the heart of a busy city. The service was excellent. And it was reasonably priced. The front desk even translated into English a note written to me in Japanese by a colleague and had the note ready for me when I arrived in the hotel. Will definitely return.

Modern quirky hotel in an excellent location (less than 5 mins from Shibuya station). There are many restaurants around too. Breakfast is decent at the hotel. Room and bathroom are decently sized for Japan. We had booked through Agoda.com which I strongly recommend not to do as they got everything wrong (not the hotels fault) - apparently its not the first time that agoda have done that...

Decently priced for Tokyo, well styled rooms (that show a little wear in places) and very friendly staff. Rooms are compact but very well designed. Decent bathroom and very quiet, never heard anything from the corridor or rooms next door. Located minutes from Shibuya station so great connections to all parts of Tokyo including sights, Shinkansen trains and the airports yet hidden away from the massive roads and train lines.- some decent restaurants and bars are located on the same street as the hotel and the two alongside- friendly staff, great Japanese breakfast included and free drinks at the hotel bar.Would stay here again or at the sister hotel

I booked this hotel in Tokyo after a whole lot of research into which hotel I should choose. I read about it in the Lonely Planet guide to Tokyo and it was a really good choice. It was hard to find from the station because I had just got off a 7 hour flight and an hour long train ride and was pretty discombobulated from arriving in thriving Tokyo, but the directions given on here are excellent. Make sure you take the South Exit and not the New South Exit, I made that mistake. It's really close to all the awesomeness of Shibuya without being in a crowded area. The first few nights I was in Japan I stayed here in a single room which was tiny but perfect for just me and sort of adorable. I decided to re-book for when I got back from Kyoto and they upgraded me to a double room which was huge compared to the single and very nice.The only channel on TV in English was MTV, but it's Japan, so what do you expect? The WiFi in the lobby is pretty good and there is a laptop you can use too. One night I went out and got horribly rained on and they had a towel for me at reception and were very nice. I really recommend this hotel, I had an enjoyable stay. The breakfast was ok, sort of strange because they served salad and soup with french toast, but that's sort of why you go to Tokyo, for different experiences.

I recently stayed at the Granbell for nearly a week while attending a conference in the Shibuya area. It was a great base for the stay - convenient location to Shibuya station, efficiently designed rooms, good breakfast and free intent in the lobby. The room was absolutely silent - no outside noise or noise from other rooms.It's not the easiest place to find from the station, though the map on the hotel website is good - if you come out of the south west entrance of Shibuya station or get dropped off by bus, you have to use the elevated footbridges to cross the intersection. Look for the "Key" guitar shop or a large bookshop - those are on the right direction and the hotel is one block farther along. You can see the hotel name in neon lights high up on the building.The rooms are small but very cleverly designed and I didn't feel cramped even with two suitcases (3 week stay, including a conference!). The bathroom is also well-designed and completely fine (not cramped). The included breakfast was a nice touch and they did have some western options, at least in one of the two restaurants. Special mention to the staff for their help in booking a complicated bus tour - it certainly didn't feel like a budget hotel, but I booked a few months ahead and e advance rate was very reasonable for central Tokyo. I'd definitely plan to stay again if I'm ever back in the area.

Stayed in a single room at Shibuya Granbell Hotel in August 2012. The hotel is conveniently located from Shibuya station, which has easy access to the Narita express train to Narita airport. It was a little difficult to find the first time. The easiest way to get to the hotel from Shibuya station is to exit from the West Gate and take the pedestrian overpass (there is an elevator for people with luggage) directly over the big street, until you see a family mart on the corner (at street level). Take the stairs/elevator down to street level. When you're facing Family Mart take the street on the left for a block, and make the first left. The hotel will be directly ahead. It is important to note that the hotel charges per person per room. There were 3 people in our group and we booked a double and a single. Found out the hard way - we had to pay extra for the second person, even though we had book a double room.The single room that I stayed in was just enough space for one person, but it was clean and well maintained. There was a twin bed, a small desk, and a mini fridge with complimentary bottle of water a day. There was no closet in the room, so I lived out of my luggage during my stay. The bathroom is only separated by a glass door, so there is no privacy. Not a big deal since the room was for one person anyway. It was difficult to control the room temperature because it was in Japanese. I was never sure which was the AC, fan, or heater. The hotel has wifi in the lobby. The hotel provided breakfast tickets to one of 2 restaurants. The restaurant at the 2nd (or was it 3rd) floor of the hotel was great. You pick what style (western, japanese, french toast, etc) that you want, and they bring you a tray. I tried the western and japanese styles, and they were delicious. The other breakfast option, however, is sorely lacking. Cona restaurant, located next to the elevators in the lobby, was HORRIBLE. They only had eggs, sausage and some bread, and everything was left out on the counter so everything was cold. Complained to the front desk and they basically said, 'sorry, nothing we can do.' The breakfast and the response of the staff is the reason I'm giving the hotel 4 stars.

This is the second time we will be staying in this Hotel. The staff are very friendly. Rooms are small... but clean , and stylish. The location of the Hotel in central Shibuya Tokyo is perfect. Breakfast is very Japanese. You are not going to get a continental breakfast here,... but then again why should you ?? ....... your in Japan!!.... lap up the culture!!

This Hotel is an amazing stay in Tokyo. The Shibuya district is simply amazing and the hotel is in an amazing location, near the train station.The hotel is very modern, clean and welcoming.The staff is very nice and the design of the hotel is very cool and sofisticated.We loved it.

We stayed in a double room that was as tine as most of double rooms in Japan. The hotel has a very good location however getting out out Shibuya station needs some skill (we were helped out by some locals as kind as ever on our trip to Japan). Hotel is clean but starts to look a little worn out. Still everything works as should. A plus for bathroom disproportionate in size to the room itself. Staff was ok, helpful with limited English skills but it was OK. The minus is about breakfast and you should beware of the one which is served in the bar / resto at the entry. Otherwise the stay was good as expected so big thanks to outher reviewers as we based our choice in Tokyo on theinr contributions.

I stayed at Granbell in July 2012 when I was in Tokyo for business. Location of the hotel is superb!
