Minutes away from the Shibuya station, main Shopping areas like Tokyu Plaza and the new mall that's opened recently there + the main shopping area of Shibuya & Cerulean hotel. Location certainly a PLUS in all aspects. The rooms, well too too small - from Tokyo standards good but from a visitor standard very small - clean, yes - well maintained yes but too cramped. There are two restaurants which provide for breakfast - one Japanese style & the other western style - however the spread of breakfast was too less - not enough for someone who looks at a good morning breakfast to start a long working day! But everything is available within minutes distance from Granbell - convenience stores, restaurant, cafes, shopping, spas and salons, everything. For business - yes great to stay - they provide free internet too! For pleasure, not suitable, especially if you are travelling with a family - the small rooms will only disappoint you.

The Granbell hotel Shibuya is very very well located! It's only 3 minutes from the Shibuya Station where you can grab all the subway lines and the Narita express!From there you can easily walk to Ebisu and the others surrounding areas.The rooms are small but that is Tokyo! You can have breakfast in 2 different restaurants and i strongly recommend the one on the second floor (the one on the GF is soso)I will definitely come back to this hotel because in terms of value, it's very good. Finally, you can find a 7 eleven nearby which is always good to withdraw money with a foreign card.

We stayed at this hotel for a family vacation with two grown up girls. It was convenient for everything -- walking distance to Ssakurahibuya station, a great variety of good eats with reasonabale prices, shopping, and walking distance to our pick up station of our day tour at the Cerulean hotel. Also the train connection to Narita. It was comfortable, had a good basic breakfast although the air conditioning was not fully operational but opening the window was OK. The hotel room was priced reasonably and the staff were attentive and spoke good English. OUr bags were shipped from Osaka and they were promptly waiting for us at the lobby when we arrived.Its easy to find this hotel when the cherry blossoms are in bloom from the Shibuya station. Its where the cherry blossoms are. Will stay in this hotel again

I picked this hotel for my last night in Tokyo, before returning home, since it's very close to Shibuya station (literally 'around the corner').Small, yet very nice, room with full glass-walled bathroom equipped with rain shower. It's a short walk to the platform of N'EX (Narita Express), so a convenient place to stay when you're looking for a good connection to your (early) flight.

We stayed at the Granbell for three nights. The hotel is very central and a good location, although a little difficult to find. The room was very small but had everything you needed, although there was not much space for cases or to walk around. The breakfast was probably the worst I have ever eaten. On the first day we had a western breakfast with a selection of poor quality food and the surroundings weren’t very clean. We decided to have the Japanese breakfast the next day which was slightly better and in cleaner surroundings. I would suggest having your breakfast elsewhere. If you want a central hotel to rest your head than is a good option.

The Good: relatively quiet in otherwise superbusy Shibuya location, trendy design, reasonable price, free internet (cable) are welcome. The Bad: although just minutes from the station you can't see the hotel behind tall buildings. I walked passed the front door twice because the sign is small and semi-hidden behind bushes. Nice design aside, the single room was business hotel-style tiny (but given this location & price, very fair). The ugly: since I live in Japan, they requested to copy my alien registration card (passports in the case of tourists). Japanese nationals do not need to produce any similar ID as they assume that all locals are honest & even guys like me who have lived here, crime-free for 25 years and counting, might suddenly go beserk and kill the first 50 people they see. Not all hotels require this but the ones that do, leave a bad impression.

I stayed at Granbell for five nights. The hotel is very conveniently located close to the Shibuya station. It's a small boutique hotel, kind of which I usually like. However, the single room was small even by Tokyo standards and it was not cleaned very well. Also, the service at the front desk was a bit so and so. If you decide to stay here, I recommend you consider booking a bigger room (which seem to have wooden floors instead of carpets, too), although it easily doubles the room price. There is aircon and it's very strong. Also keep in mind that there's only a wired internet connection in the rooms.

I've been to Tokyo five times and this by far my favorite hotel experience. Wish I'd found it sooner. Most Tokyo hotels are either big towers with little ambiance, the standard hotel chains, or, well, love hotels. The Granbell is perfectly situated 3 blocks from Shibuya Station, on a quiet side street. The room was modern and well designed (we had the Premier Double; plenty of room for my wife and I, as well as two big bags). Breakfasts were solid, and the front desk always helpful. We loved the vibe of this place, and there are plenty of little bars/cafes/restaurants nearby if needed. Tip: the Wi-Fi in the lobby was a bit spotty, and they only have ethernet cables in the rooms. BUT, if you put down a small deposit, they will give you a wireless Wi-Fi router that you can very easily connect in your room so you have a personal Wi-Fi network. Sweet. Also, there is an airport shuttle to Narita or Haneda a mere two blocks away at the Cerulean Tokyo Hotel. Super easy.

This is my first time in Tokyo and all I heard before getting here was how tiny the rooms are everywhere. And tiny they are! But the ones at the Granbell have a great feel - they put thought into making them look interesting and cozy and colorful. I stayed for 10 days and was really glad I chose this place over some boring, beige, business hotel.The location was beyond perfect - really close to the madness of Shibuya as well as the train but tucked away and quiet. I also found the staff to be super helpful and nice. They spoke some English and were incredibly accommodating when I asked if I could be moved to a corner room which they did for me no problemo. The restaurant was kinda eh but you're in Tokyo so who cares, there are countless places to choose from.If you speak English and want to hang out with other English speaking types, walk over to the Pink Cow for music and great food. They provide internet cable hook up in the room and wifi in the lobby only. I would definitely stay here again.

Granbell Hotel is in a quiet street, yet only a 3-5min walk from Shibuya Station. Reception staff were not overly friendly, but efficient. A boutique hotel, it has a cosy feel. Rooms are neat and clean and make smart use of space. The Modern Double rooms are a reasonable size but you wouldn't want them to be any smaller for two people plus luggage. Mood lighting is a theme of the hotel - even with all lights on in the room, lighting is soft and warm. It would be good to have a bright light in the room that can be switched on or off as required. Lifts and corridors are dark with their own mood lighting.Breakfast consists of a choice of western or Japanese style. We had the western breakfast each day and it's really not that great. The idea is good - having bowls of the usual bacon, scrambled eggs, salad, tuna, fruit etc out on a table, but the hot food is not kept hot. It sits there for however long it takes to be eaten and replenished. Most of the time it was cold - bacon, eggs and bread. However, when we asked for some hot, freshly cooked eggs the staff member on hand was very obliging. Not sure how they would manage in summer. I think they should invest in some bain marees. Other than that, it's a nice cosy hotel, with plenty of restaurants and cafes nearby.The Airport Limousine Bus service is a good way to get to either airport and you can catch it just around the corner at Cerulean Tower (bus is on B1 level). Btw the bar at the top of Cerulean Tower is excellent for a cocktail - ask to sit against the window for spectacular views.We've stayed at Shinjuku pretty much every other time we've visited Tokyo and Shibuya was a great alternative. It's more contained/less spread out than Shinjuku and while there are a lot of people walking the streets, it doesn't as manic. If you feel like stretching your legs, it's an easy walk to Harajuku from Shibuya.

We stayed here for two nights. The rooms are rather small for European standards, but that's the way it is in Tokyo. The design of the rooms is functional and nice. The hotel has a cafe, a pizzeria and a bar attached to it. Breakfast can be in two places (cafe or pizzeria) and I recommend the pizzeria. The buffet is not very extensive, but the a la carte food in the cafe is just poor and very small. The rooms are quiet and offer aircon. Just to clarify what might appear like it in other reviews: you do not have wifi in the rooms. There is a Ethernet plug and free wifi in the lobby and in the bar. The front desk staff we had to do with did not speak English very well. Some do speak English, but rather basic. Others hardly speak English. I would certainly recommend the hotel for its situation in shibuya (very close to shibuya station).

I stayed here for a few nights during Sakura viewing season and the close proximity to the train station for getting around town was a real plus. The area where the hotel is located actually had gorgeous Sakura and lanterns as well, really adding to the theme of my trip. The room was small but efficient and fastidiously clean. Western breakfast in the cafe downstairs was quite pitiful and I was so grateful for the second choice option of dining upstairs in the Japanese restaurant with a full Japanese style breakfast each morning while quietly planning out my plans for the day. The front desk was not super helpful for tips on eateries and probably for westerners who like the neighborhood it's just as well to simply step into the neighboring alleys and grab anything from Italian to Tapas to ramen. But for a foodie looking to have an authentic Japanese experience in a hole in the wall sushi joint, get your tips from others rather than the front desk.

The Granbell is my go-to hotel in Tokyo - great location, extremely cool rooms and great value. I stay here several times a year and normally book into a Modern Double. Yeah, it's small by US standards but the level of comfort is great and it's in Tokyo - things here are small.When I checked in this time round, I heard the pleasing words of 'as a thank you for staying here regularly, we're upgrading you to a suite room tonight - we hope you enjoy it'. Firstly - it's always nice to be appreciated and remembered when you travel, it goes a long way. Major, major brownie points to The Granbell for that. That's real boutique service.Secondly, the room was incredible. I was in the Urban Suite. This is one of the coolest hotel rooms I've stayed in, bar none. The door from the corridor looked like any room, but on entering you're in a lobby area (with cool art and lighting) where a spiral staircase leads upstairs to a glass-walled landing and your actual room. Now, it's a challenge to get your case up those stairs, but it's worth it. The room was immaculately decorated - still not massive by a US suite comparison - but big for Tokyo and ultra-stylish. Exquisite polished wood surfaces, exposed slate-brick walls, a separate washroom, standalone shower and a freestanding bath overlooking the room and the view. Very, very nice. The Nespresso maker was a very welcome touch (although no sugar, pfft) and my only real complaint was that I was only there for one night.I love The Granbell - it's everything a cool boutique hotel should be. The Modern Double rooms are fantastic - small, but stylish, comfortable and reasonable. The Suite, though, was something else. Park Hyatt or Granbell Suite? For me, easy - Granbell Suite.

We very much enjoyed our experience at this hotel. The other reviews are spot on. Fantastic location, super cute little rooms, quiet, and safe. This is the most convenient location in Tokyo that I can think of. You will have to let go of your dreams of an American size room, but you just need to get over it because everything else is so well executed. The yakitori place directly across the street is great as well.

Had a really good stay at the granbell, service was amazing. My japanese was nonexistent, but their English was pretty good. They made every effort to help out, printing out directions and maps without question. Location was really good, only a short work from shibuya station. Room sizes were pretty good and really clean and tidy with gorgeous bathrooms. Great hotel.

Very near the station (with clear directions on their website). Situated in a maze of funky little lanes full of cafes bars and restaurants, just 5 minutes walk from the madness of Shibuya proper, but unbelievably quiet and cosy inside the hotel. Friendly helpful reception staff, great breakfasts, and very clever and stylish use of the necessarily small spaces which are Tokyo hotel rooms. We will recommend this place to everyone we know and stay there again next time we go back to this fantastic city!Hotel heating was stuck on 'high' during our visit - otherwise i'd be giving it a perfect score on every index.

Stayed in Tokyo for a five day holiday, and the Granbell Hotel was excellent.The staff were very friendly, hospitable and the place - albeit small - was great. Design, layout everything. It's a really cool hotel.My only complaints - minor - are that there is no wifi in the rooms (which meant everyone would hover around the lobby on their way in and out of the hotel at all hours), and also that the climate control in the room was very difficult to use - only approximating the temperature.Apart from those minor complaints, the place is absolutely fantastic, and I'd definitely tay there again.

After living in Tokyo for a year in the Meguro/Ebisu/Daikanyama area. Now when going back for work and holiday I want to stay in a hotel close to these areas but not in Shibuya. Granbell has a perfect location in Sakuragaoka (nice part of shibuya) close distance to most points of interests in Tokyo. Rooms are small (stayed in both single room and double room, the comfortable double is ok) and breakfast not very good. Regardless of that I highly recommend the Granbell for locaction and price. Granbell is a as close to a design hotel in this part of the city. Also its very close to the Narita express. Will stay at the Granbell also in the future.

I have stayed at Granbell in Shibuya maybe 10 times. It has become one of my favorite places to stay in my favorite city, Tokyo. Location is great - especially if you like to go to Daikanyama and Aoyama. Both places are in walking distance of the hotel.I can recommend the bath view suit. That's where I normally stay. From there you have a awesome view of Shibuya at night.On the downside the entire hotel is a little run down and definitely need a work over. The service is down right bad (but I live with it because the upsides balance it out). You will have to fill your own fridge with what you need in-room (there's a convenience store nearby) and if you do not speak Japanese be prepared to somehow struggle with the from desk.Besides these less impressive observations I'll be back to Granbell again. As mentioned the location if great and the design is cool and contemporary.I find the price for the suite very reasonable too.
design hotel, but with small rooms, and bad views.if you are on a budget this hotel is fine. otherwise i would suggest the cerulean which is right around the corner.

I stayed here in October 2011 upon the recommendation of a friend and thoroughly enjoyed my stay. The room was small but comfortable, and comes complete with all toiletries necessary, including my favourite-a bath sponge! It's trendy and the location is perfect, just a stone's throw from Shibuya station. I'll definitely be back the next time I find myself in Tokyo.

This was a last minute booking for me - and thanks to QANTAS, was slightly longer than planned - and that was a real bonus.Staff were extraordinarily helpful & fun! - have stayed at 5 star hotels on business but this is now my preference.Great spot - and I was lucky enough to be upgraded to a loft room - which for the 8 days I had - was a dream.... I could hapily have moved in :-)Spot is great - great position for sights, shops and food... local bars are great and made me stretch my very limited Japanese - helped along with lots of laughing & smiles.I feel really good value - I am missing the Japanese breakfast actually!Highly recommend this as a relaxed and fun base in Shibuya

It is true, the Granbell is quite a trendy little hotel - especially for the price. And the price is a key thing here. Tokyo hotels are incredibly expensive, as everyone knows. But for $150 a night, the Granbell is worth every bit. The breakfast downstairs leaves a lot to be desired but there are plenty of restaurants close by to choose from instead. (By plenty I mean hundreds if not thousands.) The service is the usual polite, timely, great service you expect in Tokyo. And the location is a few minutes from Shibuya station. Yes, the rooms are tiny. But again, you're in Tokyo. For less than $300 a night, it's what you should expect on room size. Next time we are in Tokyo, I would imagine we will look to stay at Granbell Shibuya again.

This hotel is just the best location you could possibly ask for. Obviously this depends on what you're visiting Tokyo for, but it is the shortest walk to JR Shibuya station / Shibuya crossing, 1 stop from Harajuku, 2 stops from Shinjuku, and on the same subway line to visit Ueno park and other cool stuff. All hail the Yamanote line! For our trip, all the shopping, bars and general stuff we wanted to do was in very easy reach from this location.We stayed in the comfort double room and my gosh it is tiny. We stayed for 12 nights, so I think if you're staying for that long (or longer) then its probably better to pay a bit more for a slightly bigger room. Especially if you're like me and empty your suitcase onto the floor and then sift through mounds of clothes every day complaining you can't find anything. But if you're super neat and have a small suitcase then maybe it won't be so bad.They give you these cute little breakfast vouchers and each morning you can pick whether you go to the western style cafe, or the japanese cafe. The japanese breakfast is something you should definitely try! You can keep refilling your drinks for free there. At the western cafe you only get one drink. Something to keep in mind. Also the waffles at the western cafe were really good.Also! You must try the noodle place right next (left) to the hotel. You go in and pick a bunch of ingredients, put them in a basket, hand them to the dude behind the counter and they put them all in delicious noodle soup for you!The staff were pretty friendly, they have recommendations for good sushi restaurants and onsen around Tokyo, however their recommendations are based on a file they have, and if you ask for something that's not in their file, they don't really know what to do and just try to keep recommending what they already have.HOWEVER, the big up on this place was that we had booked our room at a particular price, and a few weeks later noticed that the price on their website had gone down (they'd added a special for our room) and we emailed them asking if there was any chance if we could get the special price and they adjusted our booking no hassles and we ended up saving some money. SUPER GOOD OF THEM. So keep an eye out for different specials on their website.Also! It was Halloween when we were in Tokyo, and they had a trick or treat basket at reception filled with lots of treats, and they were legit treats too, like full packets of M&Ms and whole snickers bars. Incredible.So overall I think this is an amazing place to stay. You can get ice from an ice machine on one of the floors so your drinks will always be super chill. But the pillows were a bit uncomfortable. Actually, make that REALLY uncomfortable. And they refill your little shampoos and soaps every day so you can bring heaps of them home as souvenirs for friends etc.

As a first timer to Tokyo, I was a little nervous about navigating my way to the hotel but it couldn't have been easier, especially with the helpful staff sending me directions and pictures. The narita express goes straight to Shibuya, which is right in the centre of all Tokyo action. You really could not get a better location, we took a fantastic walk through the heart of Shibuya, through Yoyogi Park then to Harajuku...all the top Tokyo areas. Back to the hotel though, we stayed in a single room for double use and the design was compact but clever. We loved the cute space and design. We easily fit all our luggage and ourselves in the room. You really do feel very Tokyo with the design and the bathroom was cool. They give you new slippers every day. I would recommend the Japanese breakfast, and the French toast. But give the floor 1 breakfast a miss, it was fine but there is a better ambience in the first floor breakfast room. The staff there were very sweet ( like all Japanese they were eager to help and very polite)

We didn't take the smallest room as I've heard they are tiny so watch out for that!Being in Shibuya but in a quiet back street was a blessing. You get the best of both worlds.We were also able to get the Narita Express train direct to the airport from Shibuya, so it's just a 5 minute walk.We got a great deal so always look out for them, but the price was amazing in comparison to most Tokyo hotels.My only complaint would be that I feel the hotel will soon end up looking a bit worn out. Little details like the toilet roll holder aren't brilliantly secure and may end up falling off soon. But I am being picky I know!The staff were great and very knowledgable.The bed and shower were great.Breakfast was the only downside. it's included in the price but not really amazing. I'd prefer they took it off and lowered the price a little! ;-)No view but not really bothered about that. just step outside!I love Japan and I am determined to be back ASAP. When I do I will stay there!

I stayed at this hotel last year and decided to stay here again this year, due to a combination of location, hotel amenities and value. Having used to live in Japan and only having a few days stay this time, I wanted to in a well-located area with good design. The hotel is located in Shibuya and if you are coming from Narita airport you can either take the shuttle bus which stops about 7 minutes away or the JR train directly to Shibuya. The location on a side street is quite while still only a few minitues walk from the famous Shibuya crossroad, restaurants and shops. Close by are Omatesando and Ebisu areas.The Rooms are tight, even for one person, but have everything you need. Super comfortable bed, Rain Shower, Safety box, Free Internet. Design is modern and efficient.Service is typical high quality Japanese and the staff will make restaurant reservations for you if asked and they will store your luggage if needed when you check-out.Overall, the hotel is very good for what it is. A modern well-designed base for you to discover Tokyo and not a resort hotel to lounge in. I would stay here again.
user_name:
modernn
New York City, New York

review_body: Just back from a two and a half week, first time visit to Japan and i have to say that this was my favourite hotel out of many experienced to stay. Nicely desined rooms, comfortable bed for weary legs and a three minute walk to Shibuya station. Some fantastic bars and restaurants all within easy walking distance and a ten minute walk to major shopping areas. Staff lovely and English is spoken very well if needed. Quirky yet homely hotel. I would gladly stay there again.

Ok, business hotels, single rooms are usually pretty small in Japan, but the one I had resembled a prison cell! This hotel was recommended to me by my daughter who had stayed here previously, but in a double room - maybe there is a lot of difference! The location is certainly convenient, if you come for the night life and to experience the hustle and bustle of Shibuya. I didn't feel very welcome anymore after I refused to have my ID copied, and was then asked to pay upfront for 4 nights, even though the hotel had my card details already and my full address in Japan where I am a long term resident.Breakfast coupons are offered for a cafe type place 1st floor - only unhealthy food like sausages with bacon etc, or unbearably sweet fatty pancakes, no bread. The coffee offered is of the kind that sits in a large pot on a heater for hours and is incredibly bitter.The second floor breakfast, Japanese style is very complete and there is also coffee with a better 'keep warm' system and orange juice.

I have stayed in Granbell Shibuya for 4 nights. I was there during the devastating earthquake. Hotel is located just 3 minutes away from Shibuya station and crossing , in a quieter side of the area. Hotel has very small rooms but very cleverly designed. I especially liked the bathroom. Free wifi is available in the lobby area ( a notebook station for free use as well ) and Lan connection in rooms. Breakfast is available in 3 different menus to chose from , but not very interesting. All rooms and general areas are perfectly clean for sure. Front office staff is friendly and helpful with limited language skills. They have shown a great effort after the earthquake to supply critical information and help for all guests.I liked staying there and easily chose to stay again. For the room rate paid I think its a very good deal too.I would recommend Granbell Shibuya Hotel for everyone looking for a comfortable and convenient stay in the heart of Tokyo with a fair room rate. Very cool alternative to bigger , taller hotels in a trendy way :=)

We stayed at the Granbell for three nights (one night first, then two more after we were back from Osaka). The first thing to say about this hotel is that it isn’t very easy to find, especially for first time visitors to Japan (like us). It is recommended you print out a map before leaving and even taxi drivers are not sure where it is (although four sets of locals who met us there all found it with no problem). If you are coming from Shibuya station head for the West exit then use the walkway to cross the road. When you reach the hotel it may look closed, but it isn’t, just push the big wooden rotating door! For our first night we were upgraded to a Premier Double, which we thought was a nice touch (especially as we checked in an hour or so early – no complaints from the staff). The Premier Double is quite a long room but the one we were given had no view at all. It does have a separate toilet and one of the best showers we have ever experienced.When we returned from Osaka for our second two nights we were given the Modern Double that we had booked. As it turned out we preferred this room, even though it is slightly smaller. There is no separate toilet and the shower is not quite as good as the Premier Double because you do not have a much space, but you do have a view and a larger television (which his only any use if you are Japanese – apparently Japanese hotels don’t seem to cater for overseas guests when it comes to television). The bed is the same size and even though some may consider the room small, it has absolutely everything you would need.The hotel has free internet connection and breakfast is included in the price – we would recommend picking the café over the restaurant, but if you are used to a large breakfast neither option is going to satisfy you. The staff were friendly and the hotel was clean.All Japanese hotels are expensive, but this was at the more reasonable end of the scale (roughly £165 a night for the Modern Double at current exchange rates) and we were happy to stay there and would stay again.

Enjoyed my stay at the Granbell (Shibuya). Despite some of the reviews saying that size of room was small and cramped, I had no issues with the room I stayed in. I got a Premier Double room which is bigger in size to the other room types offered, such as the Comfort Double (which I understand is the basic room) and then the Modern Double (slightly more room). The Premier Double was spacious, clean and modern and it wasn’t that much more to pay than the other room types. For two people, it was more than enough room. Worth paying that little bit extra! Breakfast was included too. The electronic toilet was cool and the bathroom (with bathtub) was nice and clean – had a great shower! The location is central and it is located in a nice quiet area, slightly on a hill. It is about 4 minutes walk from and to the Shibuya Station and a few more minutes walk to the shopping malls/building and to one of the main sites – Shibuya Crossing, photos attached. There was a great wine bar just down the road / around the corner from Granbell that had a great atmosphere (literally packed out with a mix of people – locals, tourists and ex-pats) and people were queuing outside. There is also a local / traditional wine bar right next door to the Granbell that only sold Japanese wines/alcohol but we didn’t end up going in – would have been interesting though! Restaurants and food outlets are also nearby. In terms of the hotel décor, I would agree with some of the reviews about it being too dark. The colours (or lack thereof) consist of mainly black and dark chocolate colours with some lines of red filtered through the elevators and corridors/hallway to the rooms. I read somewhere (maybe on the Japan Lonely Planet Guide) that the Granbell was also known as a “dayroom” hotel. I think that explains the reason for the colour scheme – you can hardly identify the person standing next to you in the elevator or in the hallway! It allows you to be discrete I guess. Hotel staff spoke English, service was friendly enough, it was a no fuss check in and out for us. Thumbs up for this boutique hotel.

Shibuya is a fantastic place to stay in Tokyo - very central to every place you are likely to want to visit. This hotel - although quite small - is very convenient to Shibuya Station (a short 5 minute walk) - even the Narita Express goes from this station - and a bit further walk from the central shopping district.We had a double room and we splurged on 3 single rooms for the adult daughters, and although they were all small - we loved them. The bathrooms were the best we had had in Japan.The staff on the desk were very helpful, even when we had to arrive in Tokyo a day early they did their best to accommodate us with minimum inconvenience to us.The only odd thing was that breakfast was included (which was a surprise and was great!) but the small cafe where it was served had a very odd menu (hotdogs or pancakes/ waffles and ice cream) and unfortunately allowed smoking (as it was so small there was no escaping the fumes while we were eating).Overall - I would be very happy to stay at this hotel again on my next trip to Tokyo.

The Granbell Boutique is very modern and stylish perhaps a bit dark looking. They like their garish colours of lime and yellows mixed with black. The bathroom was brilliant. I think I stayed too long under the shower as I was mesmerised by the gadgets! Me and my partner stayed in a double bedroom and although it was quite cramped you soon get use to the surrounding. The sight from our window was not very nice. Just the other block in front of us but hey, who cares. You're in Tokyo. We hardly stayed in our room. There's so much to see and do in Tokyo such as visiting the local parks, museums, temples and of course shopping! Even if you have no intentions of buying anything you have to check out the department stores especially one called Shibuya 109. This is 9 floors jam packed full of independent shops for girls!!! Brilliant. Don't worry, there's plenty for guys as well.The cool thing about the hotel is that you’re so close to their metro/tube station that's it's easy to get around although navigating around Tokyo was challenging as there's no road names! The restaurant downstairs was fine. Although I do remember the portion sizes being tiny so we had to keep asking for more. For example we ordered some fries and it came in the most tiny paper cone - more for a child. Don’t' worry we did indulge in Japanese food my favourite being King Crab which rice and sushi served at the restaurant where the film Kill Bill restaurant/fight scene was based on.The staff at GranBell were very tentative. Yes their English is not very good but you get by. It's best to ask the guys at the desk for directions before you set off on your explorations.I would def recommend the hotel to my family and friends for sure. It's comfortable and fulfilled our needs nicely.

The Granbell Hotel Shibuya is an excellent location to explore Tokyo. Only a short walk from Shibuya station (a bit hard to find the first time, but otherwise ok) but is also slightly away from the madness of the station and surrounding masses of people. The N’EX goes directly from the airport to Shibuya station, which was particularly helpful.The hotel is small and stylish and the rooms were clean and very comfortable. It is more boutique hotel than business hotel, which provides its charm. We had the ‘premier’ double, so it no doubt had a lot more room than others. The bed was excellent and the show was very good (rain shower).The complimentary breakfast was tasty – both the Japanese and the Western options were a good start to the day. Free wireless was also a plus.The staff here were very friendly and helpful and the restaurants and bars near by are worth checking out.The only down side was that the room we were in had no view at all – the window looked out to air-conditioning vents. This wasn’t great given we paid for a better room, but it was the only down side to an otherwise pleasant stay.

I wouldn't say I had a particularly bad stay at Granbell Hotel Shibuya, but it wasn't as great as I expected.As far as the good aspects, the location of the hotel is ideal. You are a 5 minute walk from the Shibuya station, but you are on the other side of the main road/highway away from all the madness. It's a bit hard to find for newcomers to Japan (i.e. no street signs at ALL in Tokyo so you need to be very handy with a map!), but it's not too hard to remember after the first time. The other good thing was the included breakfast. You have options as far as places to eat and what type of dishes you can have. We usually opted for the "western" breakfast options at the cafe. They had a different take on standards (see picture), but usually pretty good. Also, there is free internet in the lobby, but it is only 1 computer and you sometimes have to fight for it.On the down side, our room was VERY small. We definitely had opted for the cheapest double room and they put the size in square meters on their website, but you don't really appreciate it until you are there. The room was literally 7-8' wide. There was the bathroom on the left when you walked in with a shower, sink, and toilet. Then the queen size bed against the wall and along the window (there was no room at the foot of the bed). The TV sat on a desk across the walkway from the bed, but there was NO space to put our luggage that wasn't in the way. The chair in the room was also worn and dirty, which was a put-off. But they usually cleaned the rest of the room well, so it wasn't too bad. Also, the english abilities of the staff we encountered wasn't all that great. But they were very nice! For almost $600 for 3 nights, I felt that we could have found a better deal with a bit more space.

The GranBell is a great find. The rates at this property are extraordinarily reasonable and the property is one of the only examples I have ever seen of a high quality Japanese boutique property (Claska is another):Best things about the GranBell:- great value (low room rate, inclusive of breakfast and internet)- convenient location in Shibuya- large rooms for the price point (at least if you choose a double room)- stylish and efficiently decorated rooms- rain shower The biggest potential issue at this property is that it does double as a love hotel. This isn't really obvious to foreigners but Japanese guests would be able tell. I chose the property becuase of it's high rating on Tablet Hotels and it's excellent price point. Due to the dual role of the property, I'd be very hesitant to stay here if I needed to conduct business at the hotel itself. My double room was better than what I have experienced at the Cerulean Tower next door. The beds are long enough to accommodate foreigners and the property has avoided the injection molded bathrooms that are common in Japanese business hotels.This is a three star property so be aware that service levels are lower than a larger property (i.e., no bell boys) and the property lacks a business center and gym. The on site cafe and restaurants are decent.The included breakfast is quite good.

I had yet another stay at the GranBell hotel, and it was just as good as last time. The room are small compared to North American or even European Standards but that it is Tokyo for you. They are clean and compact and they have everything that you need. The beds are nice and firm and for me a pleasure to sleep on. They have a little fridge and give you lots of nice little things like a toothbrush and toothpaste, along with free water each day you stay there. They now offer a choice of breakfast in the Hotel restaurant or the small grill in the front. They have a breakfast hotdog which is a bit odd but ended up being really good. The Granbell is just off the main area at Shibuya station so it's close to alot of things and is also affordable (super for Tokyo). Staff is super nice and friendly.

We stayed here for four days and it was the the perfect base for seeing Tokyo. Its under 5 minutes walk from Shibuya station but still very quiet. Make sure you have the phone number and a map the first time you go there as its pretty hard to find - especially for cab drivers it seems - and even when your standing outside it you might miss it. The rooms are quirky and clean but pretty tiny. The beds very comfortable and the bath room is great with showers with big rain heads and great water pressure. The free Japanese breakfast is tasty and sets you up well for the day. A couple of grand cheaper a night would be good as 21,000 yen a night seems a little steep but the location means you don't spend on cabs. If your standing outside on the street, facing the hotel, to your left there is a flight of stairs (with Saki barrels and lanterns at the top) which lead down to a brilliant, hidden, very cool little restaurant/bar that is tiny and a lot of fun. You sit either at the bar on under or on top of an oversized bunk-bed style platform. It was so good we went twice.

I love this hotel. It's clean, reasonable price and just few minutes from Shibuya station. It's surrounded by nice and cozy restaurants. It's the best place if you are a tourist and explore Sibuya / Hrajuku / Ebisu area. Room service was great too.The little bar on the first floor is nice as well for midnight chat after clubbing.

Stayed here for 7 nights during a recent trip to Japan. 6 nights in the "view bath suite' and one in the "terrace suite". Both rooms were very nice, the view bath had a nice big tub with a great view of the city lights, and the terrace suite was really nicely laid out with somewhat more living room than the view bath. The staff at the hotel was very helpful in getting us restaurant reservations and helping us understand train schedules. Decent free breakfast included in the rates (strange to the American palate, but tasty). And the location is excellent, great jumping off point for exploring Tokyo. Would absolutely recommend this hotel to a couple looking for some place fun to stay at in Tokyo.

Such a trendy, cool boutique hotel. The staff was friendly and helpful (their english is not great, but they try really hard to communicate). Free wifi. Complimentary breakfast is delicious. Location is fabulous (near Shibuya station), but be sure to do map research before you go. We got so lost trying to find the hotel. Tokyo streets are so tricky and have vague street names. Even with a map, we still had trouble in Tokyo. But once we found the hotel, we were so pleased with the accommodations. The rooms are super clean. We chose a tiny room, but we didn't mind since we don't spend much time in the room. Our room rate was great value for what we got. Would highly recommend Granbell Shibuya for any traveler!

This hotel was basically perfect for our purposes. The location is amazing (steps from Shibuya station, with food/vending machines/7-11 outside the door) and an ideal as a base for sightseeing. The rooms are adorable. They're small, but very well-designed. Free internet and breakfast (DEFINITELY get the Japanese breakfast!) and helpful staff.There are tons and tons of hotels in Tokyo, but I would definitely return to the Shibuya Granbell.

Love the bathroom, the modern/efficient use of space... location is tricky (well maybe for me) but you can get a map at the Shibuya metro (ask the information desk how to get there from the West exit). Restaurants have decent food though there is much much more just in the surrounding few block alone... Staff is very friendly... Not top notch but B+In all I'm very satisfied with my stay here and will pick it again next time I'm in Shibuya

The Granbell Hotel Shibuya is a relatevly new hotel in walking distance to bustling Shibuya station in Tokyo, it offers quite spacious rooms for the money you pay which are well and intelligent designed. Everything you need is just right in front the hotel (convenient stores, bars, yaki-tori, huge underground foodcourts and so on). To make it an even better stay, next time I would try ti get a room with a view (yes there are room with almost no view). Fully recommend this hotel, hard to find a better choice in Tokyo for that money.

This hotel is excellent at what it does: clean stylish rooms in a great location. I found the staff extremely helpful and while the rooms are small I was well aware of this is advance and found my room extremely comfortable. Amazing shower, lovely bed and efficient room service. Location could not be better.

A pleasant little hotel where it's all about location, location, location. Just steps away from Shibuya station. The rooms are cute and nicely finished. Definitely designed to make the best of a small space. But for a solo traveler it is just fine, the showers and beds were comfortable, and I had no issues with noise. Breakfast was plenty good. Staff was hit or miss in terms of English abilities, but I got by. I felt the rooms were very reasonably priced considering you are in the heart of Tokyo nightlife.

I found the Granbell Shibuya to be exactly as I imagined it - great design, nice little touches, great comfort, excellent location pretty much right in the hustle and bustle of Shibuya, yet very quiet.Finding the hotel from the Shibuya station isn't too easy. When I was confronted with the confusing layout in front of the station, I couldn't make much sense of the map on the hotel website & asked at the information counter, right at the West Exit of Shibuya Station since I didn't fancy carting my lugguage around with me in the 35 degree heat after a long flight!Turns out the information desk has a printed map that easily guides you to the hotel. Easy peasy!The hotel room was impeccably clean and the bed was very comfortable. And while somewhat compact by western standards, I'm sure it's quite spacious for Tokyo.I loved the Japanese breakfast which was very interesting and nutritious. The western breakfast, by contrast, is entirely forgettable. All in all - a fantastic hotel though!

Sure, Granbell is close to the station, but so are the public lockers and they are probably more spacious. Even the double rooms are pokey here, and having a few token design touches doesn't make them comfortable. I don't consider myself a spoiled traveler - I can kip in a hostel or a tent - but I can't believe that anyone gave this hotel 5 stars.As other reviewers noted, the breakfast is not good, but you can skip it and grab breakfast in Shibuya. I do, however, expect reasonable service for this money. Even forgiving the unusually low rate of English among the staff, you can't expect much hospitality or interest.The design effort is bizarrely varied throughout the hotel. From the front door you'd think you were entering a boutique hotel (though I believe there are over 200 rooms, so the only thing boutique about it is the number of staff). The lobby is cramped, but looks nice (though on the second day, there were boxes strewn about). The rooms are seriously cramped and look like someone threw a couple of designer goodies into the mix at the last minute, and then there's a cafe/restaurant that looks like it belongs on Khao San Road. Perhaps they ran out of money. That would explain why they couldn't hire English-speaking staff. The Hotel Niwa is pretty similar in price, and a whole world apart in comfort, service and style.

I stayed in a single room for 2 nights in June 2010 and was quite impressed.My room was small, but perfectly formed and very clean. Everything I needed was there - including toiletries, towels, hangers (but no warbdrobe/storage area), hairdryer, alarm clock and refreshments. The shower worked well and had handheld or monsoon settings. The location was great, it's in a busy area, but just far enough away from the noise and also very close to Shibuya station. We got a bit lost on arrival, but the information desk at that station gave us a useful hand drawn map of the area. Hotel also has bars and cafes nearby. Breakfast was fine. They have a limited set menu and both mornings my food was okay (french toast and waffles - which included unlimted juice, water, tea/coffee).Staff were friendly and helpful. I'd recommend this hotel as a good base for sightseeing in Tokyo.

This was our first hotel we stayed in Tokyo on a 2 week trip to Japan- Stay 6 nights- Rooms modern and very Clean, small but standard for japan- Location excellent, right next to train station- Near plenty of food and shops- Staff were excellent- Young and modern area- Free internet- highly recommend
Great place. Everyone is very helpful.

I was so pleased to have chosed this hotel. It's really well situated in Shibuya. Close to the station for access around the city and not far from Centre Gai for shopping. It also has a convenience store and restaurants on the same street.For info on getting to the hotel, check YouTube as somebody has put up footage of how to walk from the Shibuya station to the hotel. It's worth knowing that you should exit via the 'South Exit' to get there without some confusion!The hotel interior is nicely contemporary and clean. I have to admit that I thought some fixtures and fittings looked a little tired but my guess is that due to it's reputation it must have a high volume of customers. The staff are all extremely helpful and friendly at all times. I had asked for a room on a high floor but when I got there decided I wanted one lower down! It was no problem to move me...then in the new room, the in-room safe didn't work so they moved me again at my request to a very nice room on the 6th floor. The room itself was small which I had expected but very comfortable and clean. The bed was very comfy and you have small flat screen TV, Kettle, complimentary bottled water, in-room safe, toiletries, torch!, clothes brush etc etc. My room had a fridge which was useful for keeping snacks and drinks cool. One point worth mentioning is that they do not have wardrobes...so be prepared to keep some stuff packed, but they do have small ironing boards and irons they can bring you should you need themFor breakfast there are three options, one Japanese style and two Western style. They were decent (but not massive) portions and if you are veggie like me it is easy enough to get around and ask them to miss out the bits you don' want :) There is free internet in the reception area and there is also a cafe right next door which has a connecting door straight in to the hotel. You can get Western style food and drink in there and the prices and food aren't bad.If you are partial to a cigarette you will be pleased to know that you can book a smoking room for your stay.Would stay here again without hesitation.

Stayed in Granbell Shibuya for a few days in April 2010.The price was fine and the location was perfect, as it was a few minutes away by foot from the Shibuya train station (comes in very handy when you need to the take the Narita Express to the Narita Airport.).The single room was very small: no closet (you hang your clothes on a hook or two), no bathtub (shower only) and a crapy view from the window. The walls are rather thin, I could hear the neighbour. But well, this is Tokyo!Free internet connection in the room (Cable, no WLAN). If you stay 10 nights, you get one night free. I had the Japanese breakfast which was fine, but was told by my friends that the European breakfast was awful.

The Granbell is in the super trendy Shibuya but on a quiet side street (very close to the station) so you're near the action but not in it. They offer a significant discount for "extended stay" reservations, meaning staying 2+ nights. This allowed us to afford a larger room (relatively speaking for Japan) and be quite comfortable for the week we stayed there. The rooms are stylish and have free Internet and a deep soaking tub. The breakfast is included - get the Japanese breakfast over the Western one and you'll be ok. There is no real lounge/common area in the lobby,, but you're staying in Shibuya...what do need to hang out at your hotel for?! The staff spoke English fluently and were very helpful. The Granbell got our vacation off to a fantastic start!

HIGHS:- Great location.- Modern design.- Confortable beds.- Great bathrooms.LOWS:- The worst hotel breakfast we have ever had. We took the Continental.The omelette looked like it was made the day before as well as the cuts of the ham, all dried... It tastes like airplane food, cooked hours before... We wonder if they have a kitchen... They didn't even have some milk... incredible. - Common areas need painting, carpet replacement,... not very well kept.- A bit more cleaning.- Lack of a sitting area. They do have a bar, but not from the hotel.- Breakfast room is not as designed as the rest of the hotel, no taste at all.TIPS:- For a bit more money, ask for the Superior Twin room, is worth the extra money you pay.High celings having a deep sensation of space, located at the topfloor by the suites. There is just one Premier twin. Look at the pictures I attached.After the Shibuya Granbell stay, we slept at the Ginza Mitsui Garden. Almost same price, but much more well kept, better design, incredible views... also by a subway station. Better value.Even though, if you like Shibuya, you won't find a better design hotel in this area.

Don't get me wrong, the room was tiny (the first morning I woke up, swung my feet off the bed and stepped right into my husband's suitcase) ... but, larger than expected. No TV in Engish, which was fine because we were never in the room. Breakfast is included but not good. Service was either fabulous (they helped a lot with reservations) or difficult due to language barrier. But, overall, we're glad we stayed here because it didn't cost a fortune compared to other places and the location was great. We walked 3 minutes to the Metro every day. We also kept a blog about our visit, with other suggestions: http://thedelowes.wordpress.com/2010/04/18/tokyo-japan/

My friend and I each had our own (adjacent) singles. Simply put: the rooms are tiny. In the single rooms, there's not even room to put your stuff. No closet, and limited floor space. But, it was cheap, and it was nice to have our own space, regardless of the size. The hotel itself is both quaint and funky. Pretty low frills, but it's modern and they do well with the space they have. The location was great. It's on the other side of the main intersection as most of what you want to do in Shibuya, so you're constantly using the overpass stairs to get anywhere you'd want to go to. That said, it's all within walking distance, and the neighborhood has a fantastic buzz.The staff was pleasant and helpful, there was a computer in the (small) lobby. If you don't need a ton of space, and don't have lots of "stuff", this is a fun and affordable hotel.

Groovy room! We got a semi-double for one night. Loved the glass wall bathroom. Comfortable, firm bed with good reading lights. Breakfast was included with the room. We opted for Japanese (over the Western) - it was good. Fun hotel.

I thoroughly enjoyed my stay at this small hotel (and in Tokyo). It is really well located to the action/transport (and the Airport Limo pickup at the Cerulean) but tucked away enough to give you some peace and quiet. The staff were super friendly and helpful with nothing too much trouble for them. I stayed in one of the modern double rooms which was very comfortable. The bathroom was well stocked with amenities and spotlessly clean as per Tokyo/Japanese standards in general. I wouldn't wish to be spending great lengths of time in the room however and if your are the sort of person that likes to hang out in a room then the Granbell probably isn't the place for you. Free wi-fi was also a plus. Good sized HDTV however a few more cable channels would have been handy. CNN & MTV are all that are on offer in English. Just a couple of small things. The cafe/bar at the front of the hotel is great for a quick, cheap, tasty lunch but not open til 11. The restaurant on level 2 is average for coffee/breakfast and I chose to eat outside of the hotel each morning which was a bit of a hassle. The breakfast is included so I guess you get what you are given. For dinner / lunch however there are some excellent places to eat around the hotel.Also, as it is a small hotel and not a five star, dont expect all of the trimmings. No minibar or a porter to help you out with luggage. In respect to this you basically get what you pay for but as long as you are prepared for that then you are aok...I wasn't and I still survived. lol ;)Example of service: I left a couple of things at the hotel. I emailed them when I got back to Sydney...they got straight back to me after locating them and they emailed a photo of the items for me to confirm visually that they were mine! Amazing...what other country offers that level of professionalism in service.I liked this hotel alot...but mostly...I just loved Tokyo generally!

Had a three night stay here in mid January, booked the comfort double.Had almost no trouble finding the hotel. It's about a 3 minute walk from the Cerulean Tower (where the airport limo bus drops you and picks you up, if you're going that route). Based on the price we were paying (17,000Y) I had few expectations for the hotel, but was pleasant surprised by the lobby and check-in areas. We were quickly checked in and on our way to our room.The funky elevator lighting and hallway lighting are typical of a mid-range boutique style hotel, and I was very happy with the spotless (albeit compact) room. My previous stays in Tokyo have been at the Intercon and Hilton, with full-size western style rooms, so this was a bit of fun.We cleaned up and hit the town.The next morning we had absolutely no hot water in our room. I went down to the desk to get it looked after, and was immediately given keys for another room so we could shower and be on our way. They asked us to pack up our stuff in case they couldn't rectify the water situation.Upon returning that night we had been given an upgrade to an absolutely cavernous room (just kidding, but at least I could walk around the bed). Kudos to all the hotel staff who made this fix pleasantly and seamlessly for us. Typical Japanese customer service - wish we had that in North America.The breakfasts were just as others have mentioned in their reviews. Unfortunately we are vegetarians, one with a fish allergy, but the waiter got it pretty much right every morning (except the fish sauce packet in the fermented soy beans).The wired internet was fast and worked flawlessly, the wifi somewhat less. If/when I'm back in Tokyo, I will definitely stay here again. The combination of location, price and service is difficult to beat. And - I would heartily recommended it to friends as well.

We spent our first 2 nights in Tokyo at the Shibuya Granbell. It was a good choice - central at only 2-3 minutes walk from Shibuya station, but nicely tucked away so as to be quiet. Unlike some previous reviewers, we didn't find it far at all from the station - but we don't tend to travel with more than we can easily carry, even on long trips, so the easy walk up and over the pedestrian bridge didn't involve lugging a heavy suitcase.The room was comfortable and modern, and no smaller than your average Tokyo hotel room. The bathroom was great - awesome shower, great products replenished daily and one of those toilet control panels that looks like it belongs on a flight deck.The Japanese breakfast was good, while the western breakfast was not. But hey, when in Japan... what do you expect?Our view wasn't a Tokyo city skyline, but I the side alley we looked over was intriguing nonetheless, and this wasn't the kind of trip where we'd be spending a lot of time in our room - there is too much to see and do. We found this a great base to walk lots of this part of Tokyo, from Shibuya to Harajuku and Meiji-jingu.The staff were efficient, and the kind I would expect to find in a business hotel. There did seem to be a mix of business and leisure clients at this hotel.If we wanted to stay in this part of Tokyo again we would probably stay here. However, we were far more fond of the shitamachi - the older, more traditional part of Tokyo (Asakasa, Ueno) - and next time will probably base ourselves there for our entire stay in Tokyo.

It would've been almost impossible to find, but thanks to Google Street View map and several other maps (including the one from their website) learned how to get there from Shibuya station. But now that we know where it is, it's very easy and handy!We wanted to stay somewhere in Shibuya because I wanted to be right in the actions and happenings of Tokyo, day and night. Granbell Hotel Shibuya could not have been better located! It was so close to the Shibuya station, but quite hidden away at the same time, making it a nice and quiet spot to sleep in at night. It is also surrounded by so many restaurants including our favourite yakitori! We're a bit of a foodie and this was a perfectly situated hotel for that!We stayed at the Annex Cozy Suite room and it was as trendy and swanky as it appeared on the website. The living area was more on the ground floor, and it was tiny but functional. The upper floor was where everything else was: the bed, the walk-in wardrobe, the big bathroom (big in Japanese hotel standards), and the ultra modern toilet. There wasn't much of a view but we didn't worry too much about it. The bed was very comfortable but the provided yukata or pyjamas looked ridiculous on us. The amenities and toiletries were very good and abundant (they replenished it daily). The rain shower was GOOD, although we always seemed to make a big puddle outside the shower booth at the end of it. The room has 2 TV's, one in the living room downstairs, and one upstairs facing our bed, and I didn't think there was an English language TV programmes (not that we were interested to watch one). There's free wi-fi in our room. The bedroom itself wasn't that big, but knowing that space is premium in Tokyo, we felt it was spacious enough. Plus the interior design was just so cool, we enjoyed it very much.There was also a complimentary breakfast, a choice of 3 styles of food: western, French and Japanese. They were served in the hotel's restaurant and it was cosy and modest. My partner always picked the western one which consisted of ham or bacon, omelette with ketchup all over it, plus salad and some kind of tasty clear soup. I went for the Japanese one, which was a big meal of hot steamed rice with fried fish fillet, and miso soup, japanese salad, some pickled, nori and fermented soybeans. My sister picked the French one, which was a French toast, same western style of salad and soup. I liked my Japanese breakfast but the western and French ones were average but it was filling and free. The menu didn't change the entire we were there, except the switch between ham and bacon, and type of fish served for the Japanese breakfast.The receptionist staff didn't speak much, and at first I thought they didn't speak enough English but soon realised they spoke and understood good English. They were just not chatty, I guess. I felt the service was up to standard, but nothing more. However, knowing that it was my sister's birthday one day, they left a congratulatory letter and a birthday present in her room which I definitely did not expect. What a nice touch! The present was Japanese confectionaries put together and it was just a pleasant surprise. The hotel staff also passed it on to the teppanyaki restaurant where we booked for the birthday dinner. My sister was surprised with a cheesecake dessert with a sparkler on it! We were most impressed!The exterior and the lobby of the hotel was not much to look at. There's one laptop you could use for internet etc near the receptionist desk. The room was very nice. My sister stayed in the Annex Single room and while it was very small, it was sufficient and the design made it very cosy and comfortable to stay in. The biggest downside was the fact that you have to walk up and down the steps/stairways of the pedestrian bridge across the huge street. It wasn't fun lugging all our bags from and back to Shibuya station, through all those steps. While it is very close, but with heavy bags it did feel like we were walking for miles.

Stayed here for 4 nights at the start of November in a Modern-Double room. I found their web-booking system a bit poor, and had to e-mail them to see if my reservation went through.Unfortunately, I could only have a non-smoking room for the first 2 nights. For the last 2 nights we had to move to the smoking room. I was worried that the smoking room would stink, but it didn't. In fact, if they didn't tell us, I'd never have guessed that it was a smoking room.They even transferred our luggage from the rooms while we were out.The room was small, but I guess they all are in Tokyo. Also, a bit on the dark side, and our room had no view to speak of (4th floor). The shower was great, - very powerful, and the bathroom had a hi-tech loo as well !!There was free access to the internet in reception and they also had a bar which stayed open till 2am.The breakfast was a poor effort, but as it was included in the price we eat there. They staff were very courteous and professional (as everyone is in Tokyo!!)Its only a few minutes walk from Shibuya station, but when you arrive (with heavy luggage) its a bit daunting navigating the pedestrian foot-bridges. The trick is to use the ones which have a ramp in the middle - (when you come out of the west-exit, don't use the steps nearest to you on the left, but cross the road on your right and use the ram to your left). There are plenty of restaurants and bars nearby.If I was going back to Tokyo, I would stay in this area again, but would perhaps try the Cerulean Tower hotel, in the hope of getting a better view.

Located very close to the Shibuya station but on the quieter side from where all the action is, this boutique hotel attracted mainly young couples and singles. The rooms were tiny but decorated in bright colors with a trendy see-through wall into the modern bathroom - a fun room. Unexpected plusses included breakfast and a free internet access computer in the lobby. It was conveniently located for sightseeing, shopping, clubbing, and everything else you might be doing in Tokyo. The only problem we encountered was the hot temperature of the room. It was November, so air conditioning was no longer operating. The front desk gave us the latch that allowed us to open our window. We would stay here again.

I stayed here with my boyfriend in Feb this year. It seemed like a long way away from the Shibuya train station when lugging your luggage in the pouring rain (the only time it rained our whole trip- on the way to the hotel!) But after this we realized just how great the location was. Just a quick walk down the street and over the pedestrian bridge and your at the Shibuya main station. The hotel itself looks cool and very modern, the decor in the rooms is great, nice flat screen TV. The room pretty much just fit a double bed with a little room next to it to move around, but all hotel in Tokyo will be like this! The breakfast is nice, but be wary of the room service- my nachos consisted of about 3 corn chips! very small servings for the price. Awesome noodle restaurant next door where you pick your own ingredients from noodle type to vegies to meats! Close to shops and restaurants also.

I was in Tokyo for work in October 2009, my usual accommodation, Oakwood Apartments in Roppongi now only allow stays of more than 30 days. I came across the Granbell Shibuya purely by accident whilst trying to book another hotel. From the website, it looked quite fresh and was in a convenient location so I decided to give it a go and booked a premiere suite for 6 nights.Firstly, getting there is a problem if you have bulky luggage as I did. I got the Narita Express train to Shinjuku Station and took a cab from there. Of course, this being Tokyo, the driver will have problems if you are not going to a mainstream big hotel. Nevertheless, I called the hotel and the staff guided the driver there. The cab journey should cost no more than 2000 Yen. If you have light luggage, make your way to Shibuya Station (many ways to do so via trains, costs vary, consult your guide book), follow signs to South Gate Exit, go through that gate and take the West exit (its either East or West at the South Gate). You will see a pedestrian ramp bridge, go up that and walk towards the direction of a huge musical instrument shop and then go down the ramp when you’ve reached the end. In front of you, you should see a Kirin City Restaurant, walk towards that, turn right and you should be going up a slight hilly street. The hotel entrance is quite discrete, but look for hairdressers called PROS on your right and the hotel is exactly opposite this. Phew!The lobby and the reception area is quite simply decorated and to be honest, not really that appealing. Check in was fast and efficient, the staff here speak very good English and were polite and professional. I personally thought the lifts had a nice ambience, very glossy and very dark.My suite was on the 8th floor, the theme of the lifts continues through to the corridors only less gloss. There is a vending machine on this floor but I’m not sure if there is one on all floors, sells the usual popular Japanese beverages: cold coffee, cold green/herbal tea, beer and water. My room, and I must stress this is my own personal opinion, was not very well designed. I think my judgement was impaired when I realised there was no desk to work at. From the pictures, you can see that the downstairs area contains nothing but a mirror, other than putting my shoes there, I had no other use for it. The sitting area was cosy and there was a nice Nespresso machine. The TV was a nice 42 inch model, fully 1080p hi definition but when you’re in Tokyo, there are much better things to do than watch TV. The bed was massive but the mattress is a bit hard for my liking, again this is down to personal choice. Also, the hotel is 3 years old now and certainly in my room, there were dents, scratches and scuffs galore. I think the overriding problem with this room was that there was too much emphasis on the freestanding bath, it really took up too much space. My opinion maybe coloured by the fact that I was working and would have preferred more working space. I asked myself the question, if I had been on holiday would I have appreciated this more? Probably not, if spectacular baths are your thing, they have a Bath View suite on the 13th floor which you can have panoramic views across Shibuya whilst taking a bath. One note to add about the washing facilities, the shower was fantastically powerful, however, the flow of water draining is very slow, there were minor floods every night!Breakfast is included, but skip it and explore Shibuya for something better. On a catering note, I ate at both hotel restaurants, one western, one Japanese, both were OK but I wouldn’t want to eat there every night.As for the surrounding area, well, Shibuya is world famous so consult you guidebooks for an in depth review of what’s hot and what’s not.In conclusion, would I stay here again? It’s a yes, but only if it was a personal holiday. The hotel lacks a business centre but there is free ADSL in all rooms (WiFi in suites, cable connection in other rooms). Would I stay in that room again? That’s a definite no, I would pick another suite or maybe a Premier room instead. I did see some of the smaller rooms when they were being cleaned and they are really very small. It’s OK for those who just want to party and crash, but if you like to chill and unwind in your room, get something bigger.Overall, quite impressed with the Granbell Shibuya, it’s a definite plus to the Tokyo hotel scene. Thanks for reading this long winded review and I hope you have a nice time in Tokyo, wherever you stay!

First of all; the location is great. 2 minutes from JR Shibuya, which connects you with almost everywhere in Tokyo. We had to wait pretty long until we could finally check-in which was a bit of a pain. The room then was actually smaller then expected...we had a premier double (if I'm not mistaken) room which was about 23'000 yen per night. Bathroom was nice, the bed was great...nice sheets and everything. The TV though wasn't very good. The minibar was empty, the fridge didn't really work anyway. Same with the AC. It was too warm/hot in the room...I tried to figure out the AC, without success. Spoke to the reception which told me, that it can only heat in March/April. Pretty weird. No WLAN aswell, we had to use the (short) cable.The reception though was very good at pointing out directions though. The (included) breakfast was not good at all. Not worth it. Overall a good hotel at the perfect location, but they could do sooooo much better.

So, Tokyo's pretty cool, but it's kind of difficult to find anything other than the major hotels in town - previous trips have ended up at the Ginza Tobu or Dai-Ichi hotels (both perfectly OK, but a bit worn and not so cool). But this time, the Granbell beckoned. And what a result.Fabulously located (2 minutes walk from Shibuya station) on a quiet enough, but not dead, backstreet and super, super cool. From the immense wooden door that leads you in to the ultra-cool rooms, this place was exactly what I've always been looking for in a vibey Tokyo hotel, but never been able to find. The rooms aren't huge - hey, it's Japan, and Tokyo at that - but go for a deluxe double upgrade and they're more than big enough, and very, very stylish and comfortable. The bar/restaurant at the front of the hotel pop.pie serves great casual food (I had an incredibly painstakingly made chilli-dog that was nothing short of excellent) and good drinks and, extremely rarely for Japan, is open 24 hours. Need champage, a hamburger or an espresso at 5am? Now you knwo where to find it.So it's ultra-stylish, it has a cool bar and restaurant and it's bang in the middle of one of Tokyo's coolest districts. Must be expensive then? Nope, it's a bargain. Seriously, silly cheap.No question, next time I'm back in Tokyo, this is where I'm staying.

Great location, cafes, wine bars right next to it, 3mins from railway station, 4 from Shibuya crossing. Rooms funky, a few quirks. Got a twin room for my kids, - shower room can be seen even with curtain across, which was a bit iffy. Breakfast included but not worth the price. Comfy enough, wi-fi in lobby a bit dodgy sometimes. Worth staying at though - good value, great location and pleasant place.

My husband and I stayed here during a 3-week trip to Japan. We stayed here for four nights. My sister joined us for a leg of the journey and stayed in a single room in this hotel. The rooms are very small, so this isn’t a good choice for groups or families. Most of the people staying in the hotel are businessmen, solo travelers, or couples. The restaurant just outside of the hotel (Pop) provides the room service and is truly awful, especially if you’re used to American cuisine. We ate at the restaurant (not room service) once after a long night. We didn’t eat at the hotel restaurant except for breakfast.The hotel décor is sort of pop art/mod and the rooms efficiently use space. This is a big deal staying in Tokyo. The hotel staff was very helpful in helping us to make dinner reservations and the morning continental breakfast was pretty standard for Japan.The location is a couple of blocks from the Shibuya crossing, making it an easy walk to Shibuya and to the train/subway station. It turned out to be a good base for getting around in Tokyo. I usually try to stay in an area of town with nightlife, so that I can easily walk or take a cab back to the hotel late at night. For getting around the city, staying near the Shibuya or Shinjuku stations makes it pretty easy and there is plenty to do at night.The hotel isn’t cheap, but it is Tokyo. I chose this hotel because of the location and price. If I were going back to Shibuya, I would definitely stay at Granbell Hotel.Pros:Location (just outside of Shibuya station)Interior décorHelpful staffCons:Small roomsExpensive, but reasonable for neighborhood. Cheaper places to stay in Tokyo, but not many of them in Shibuya.

This is a great little hotel in a very convenient location a short walk from Shibuya Station. The hotel is located in the quieter part of Shibuya up a bit of a hill but nothing too bad and surrounded by some nice small restaurants. I only stayed here for two nights as my plans changed and couldn’t get a room at the hotel I had booked for the remainder of my stay in Tokyo. I stayed here in early September 2008 and it appeared that the construction mentioned in previous reviews had finished as when I checked in I was told I would be the first guest in the room I was given. Room 611 was bright and small but I was expecting that, everything was nice and fresh as you would expect with it being brand new. Despite the room being tiny it was really nice and had everything I needed for a two night stay, comfortable double bed but due to the size of the room it can only be accessed from one side as the other three sides are up against the wall which gives you an idea of the length of the room. Great glass enclosed shower room with a fantastic shower with both a rainhead shower and handheld shower and a very high tech automated washlet which to my surprise had the seat pre-heated. The shower room is exposed to the bedroom but does have a curtain that you can pull across for privacy, but given the size of the room I doubt it would be suitable for two people and if it was they would probably not be concerned about privacy. I paid 10,400 Yen per night and at the time the Australian $ was above 95 yen to the dollar which made the hotel great value for Tokyo. Unlike some other hotels I have stayed at in Tokyo this hotel had a nice outlook from the room looking back towards Shibuya Station, nothing outstanding but better than a brick wall a metre away like in some. The staff were very helpful and was able to check in a little before the normal check in time. The lobby isn’t very big and isn’t one designed to spend any time in like some, there is a café/bar at the front on street level which I didn’t use. The rate I booked didn’t include breakfast but for some reason I was given a voucher for breakfast on one day which was taken in the hotel restaurant on the first floor, It is not a buffet style as in most hotels but rather a choice of three or four set menus and don’t assume like I did that half boiled egg was a misprint for hard boiled egg, it is actually only half cooked. The room had a full set of amenities, shampoo, razor, toothbrush, small fridge, free internet access nice little LCD TV, safe big enough for a laptop but strangely located in a drawer with an opening top. There isn’t much room for suitcases or clothes just a few hooks on the wall to hang a few things and your suitcases will be on display all the time. There is a ledge under the window which came in handy for putting a few things on and there is a small cupboard under the window that has a small folding stool in it for a visitor I guess.The only odd thing about the hotel was that in the corridor on my floor there was a very strong smell, not unpleasant and in the end I pit it down to the new construction that had just been completed it was kind of like a new car smell, but probably well and truly gone by now.Overall I think this is a terrific hotel in a great location and if you want more room they do have bigger rooms available at bigger prices. One of the great things about Japanese hotels is that they do seem to have a variery of room sizes with corresponding prices so if you want to save money you can stay in a small room and pay a smaller price.

Stayed here for 1 night. A lovely, quirky hotel, very modern, with smallish rooms but plenty big enough for your suitcases and room to move around. The bathrooms are glass surrounded so remember to pull the curtain round if you want privacy! The bathrooms have the usual compliment of toiletries and are very clean with a lovely shower. The staff were lovely - they booked a restaurant for us and gave us good directions to all sorts of attractions. You can leave your bags with them when you check out. 2 good bars at front and back of hotel with decent prices. Located close to the station - slightly inconvenient for wheeling suitcases as you have to cross a bridge but no big deal. Breakfast is ok - not brilliant but enough to fill you up. Would stay here again.

My gf & I stayed two nights. We had 48 hours to experience essential Tokyo during a long layover on way to Australia. I did much research and chose Shibuya / Granbell as being "on the grid" of the Yamanote Line which would take us to the top10 attractions we'd have time to see. Their staff was very helpful answering my many emailed questions in advance. I paid them extra to have a bouquet of local flowers waiting in the room and they did great. We got non-smoking Comfort Deluxe double for 14700/16800 yen which was awesome deal & we did it by watching occupancy on website and waiting till 15 days before, when the price dropped because they still had vacancy.
