Risky strategy & worked for us in Feb offseason during global financial meltdown; YMMV. We took limo bus from Narita which was fairly cheap and direct, but be sure to have a copy of the Cerulean-to-Granbell map as the final 4 blocks are not obvious and nobody speaks English. The Granbell is very close to Shibuya station and the JR Yamanote line worked great for us to hit top10 attractions -- just bring cash 'cause our American VISA was not accepted and many ATM's in area wouldn't take our card; eventually we found 7-11 AMT that worked; you might wanna get cash at airport. We did all-day passes for JR and that worked great. Breakfast was comforting, good, all-you-can-eat. We stayed in annex and room was surprisingly large after reading reviews here but also we were in Comfort Double. Electric bidet toilet is an eye-opener. During day we shared an elevator ride with a classy pretty but yes-for-sure-you're-a-call-girl worker. Some ppl are bothered by that and yes it is there. Internet used a cable, was fast, free, no problems with it. USA-style working outlet available in our room for laptop. Desk had 24/7 staff available. Building felt very secure, safe, good neighborhood. When flying out, we took Yamanote Line to Ueno and the Kesei Limited Express from there to airport 'cause by then we were experts.

Personal little boutique hotel close to the Shibuya station. Nice design everywhere from bathroom knobs to the front door (where's the handle?). Single rooms are small, only 12 square metres, but comfortable. Not much services – there's vending machines for snacks and drinks at the reception and just one or two person at the counter. Breakfast is decent, served at the trendy bar downstairs. The shuttle bus to/from the airport stops at the nearby Cerulean Tower.

I decided to try this hotel after reading some of the reviews here. I booked a single room on the hotel webstie at a rate of 11,000 Yen per night. After checking in, I found myself in a tiny, suffocating room. There was no space to turn around, no storage space for luggage, and no desk to work or even open the laptop. Nice details, but too small to be true! Thus, for only 3,500 Yen per night I upgraded to a Double Room, single use. The room was larger, with one desk plus a round table, queen size bed, storage space for clothes. Overall feelins is that the hotel is clean, modern, sleek and service very attentive. Staff was very polite - not a surprise in Japan.Breakfast was OK, nothing special. There are several coffee shops and bars around, so you could always choose something else. I wouldn't recommend the single room, it is really small. OK, this is Japan, but it doesn't mean you have to suffocate in a 10 square meter room for 150 USD per night. I would definitively recommend the double room instead. In regards to the location, the hotel seats right in the heart of Shibuya, plenty of options in terms of shopping, dining and clubbing. You won't get bored in this area of Tokyo!

Very hip, modern and very comfortable boutique hotel about 3 blocks from Shibuya Station. I paid about $140 for a nice double, separate shower and separate toilet - all very modern and hip. Solid breakfast, either western or Japanese, included with coffee/tea/juice.Very comfortable and boutique with yukata that are kind of an westernized version, and very high quality.Overall, this place was very reasonable, hip, modern, and I thought a good value just off of Shibuya central in an area with lots of great Japanese and mix of restaurants and bars.Free broadband in room.

Excellent value, stylish, well-located, well-insulated, mid-price hotel. Nice japanese breakfast options. Cosy bar area. Rooms are small: half the space is taken up by the bathroom. Little space for storing clothes. But strongly recommended.

My husband and I travel a lot. Since we moved away from Japan a couple of years ago, we need to find a good place to stay when we went back visit our friends thereI did a lot of research to find a nice petite hotel..we both were very happy that we made a right decision to choose this one. Hotels in Tokyo were mostly super tiny and the rate is not cheap...you don't expect what was inside the room..cause they would look mostly very alike despite which business hotel you stay with. We found out this hotel is a lot more better then we expectedwe stayed in [premiere double] room which is relatively more space than the single ones. I love their interior design a lot..nice shower room..and a sepereate good bathtab..which is not easy to find good one in Tokyo. The location is great...few mins walking distance from Shibuya Station. we also went to Tokyu Department to buy some super yummy cakes there..trust me...you really want to visit there once...we bought two back to the hotel..had a nice afternoon tea in our room.Their staff were very helpful...we had great time there..will definitely stay with them when we go back..

Stylish and reasonably priced. This hotel; was in a great location for everything. Little difficult to get large bags from the station to the hotel due to the overpass, but that is the only draw back. Great restaurants nearby and yummy breakfasts everyday.

Absolutely awesome location - a really short walk from the West Exit of the Shibuya Station, and Shibuya is a great base in Tokyo.I had a single non-smoking room and there certainly wasn't room to swing a cat, but I didn't mind as I only had a backpack and really only needed a bed to sleep on. The bathroom is enclosed in glass to let in the light, and it was well appointed with awesome water pressure. If you were planning to squeeze a second person into the slightly-larger-than-normal single bed, hopefully you won't mind watching them shower.Service was fine, but I didn't do anything more than check in and check out. I didn't ask any questions regarding sight seeing etc. so I can't comment on that.If you're anything like me you look for some clear directions in Trip Advisor reviews to find hotels, so here's some directions you might find helpful. A quick look on Google Earth helps as well!I grabbed the NEX / Suica option to get from Narita (a great deal). As it was an early trip in, I had to change from the Narita Express to Yamanote at Shinagawa, which is a smaller station so getting from one line to the other was a breeze.When you get to Shibuya, make your way to the West Exit. Plenty of signs point the way. When you exit, you'll face a number of bus stops - head left past the toilets and straight up the stairs which go across the road but below the overpass. Keep walking and head down the stairs in front of you. You'll walk along the road which has the red paving leading out of it. A short walk along this road will lead to an intersection - walk up the hill on the road which has the circular paving (it's on the right). The hotel is about 20 metres on the left.

The Granbell Hotel is a small, chic, boutique-y hotel in the heart of Shibuya. The hotel is super clean (wouldn't expect anything less from Japan) and the receptionists are polite and courteous. I stayed in the smallest room, and it is small but comfortable. Not much room to spread out, but if you're looking for a great place to crash, but don't want to stay in a hostel, this is a great find. Plus it's value for the money. I highly recommend.

The Granbell is conveniently located next to the Shibuya train station with easy access to all of shops and restaurants of the area. As opposed to an industrial hotel park, the Granbell is integrated into a neighborhood where you can get a feel for the daily rhythms of the people who live in the city. Similarly, the small number of units give the hotel an intimate feel as well. The accommodations live up to the brochure description as 'designer' -- I particularly liked the glass enclosed shower room with overhead shower nozzle and deep bathtub. Another feature that I found particularly welcome was the adjoining 'Plate of Pies' bar/restaurant -- a 24-hour hipster hang out that serves a limited menu and full bar. The reasonable room rates seal the deal for me.

I am giving this a five star rating due to the price, location and cleanliness. It is truly an excellent value and I had a great stay for three nights in April 2008. The location is close enough to all the action of Shibuya, but just outside enough to have peace and quiet. It's definitely walking distance to the train station, and also walking distance to the famous cross walk that we all know Shibuya for. The staff was very friendly and my single room was the size I expected along with a very nice shower that confirmed the other reviews that I had read.....also had free internet. I would stay at the Granbell again with no worries.

We loved this hotel, it's in a perfect location in Shibuyain a quite street that has great little bars & restaurants.It's only a few minutes walk from the Shibuya train station with cool department stores, shops and the main square.As a designer, I loved the style & feel of the rooms. Theywere a good size for Japanese standards. We booked aroom that had construction outside our window...the staffwere only to happy to upgrade us at no extra fee.The cafe underneath does a breakfast, it's a little expensive& not very satisfying. We discovered a western style cafe down the road, they do a great coffee & sandwichfor good prices.From the airport it's tricky to get to. The airport bus will dropyou off at a big chain hotel nearby, then you catch a taxito this hotel. There are no direct airport buses. It's worth it.Well recommended.

When I found the Granbell online I was very excited, it looked very funky and in a great position in Tokyo. Maybe it was because we had just stayed at the wonderful Ryokan Shiraume in Kyoto, but I found the Granbell disappointing. The room was a decent size, still small but not tiny like some in Tokyo. A fantastic shower with great water pressure. A very hard bed, little hanging space and nowhere to put suitcases except on the couch. There was construction going on (an annex being built till June '08) so we had no view but there was no noise either, they don't seem to start at 7am like they do here. The staff spoke very little English, and were very unhelpful with things like restaurant bookings and train timetables. The breakfast was definitely not worth 1000 yen, all you get is a black coffee and a ham and cheese mini roll, you'd be better off going to Excelsior Coffee or somewhere else down the road.Still, if you want somewhere reasonably priced and quite stylish to stay in a good spot in Tokyo, this is it. If you are expecting good service and 'five star' luxury, go elsewhere.

Normally I 'm sure the Granbell is a great place to stay but I wanted to back up what has been said about the building works. The hotel is building a very large annexe with work going on every day betwen 8am - 6pm until at least June 2008. The annexe is adjoining many of the double/twin rooms and the work is a few feet away from the window so if you are looking for a quiet or romantic break at the Granbell - don't bother for now! I have attached a photo to show the view! from the room. Most annoyingly the hotel didn't mention the work when booking or on the hotel website, if they had I certainly wouldn't have booked the Granbell this time. The single rooms at the front are not affected. Good points - it's very well located, well designed, the staff are pleasant and we liked the bar.
Great hotel, brilliant location. The room are compact but very nice. Nice bathrooms.All at a good price.

We (family of 4) have just returned from 4 nights at the Granbell and it was great! Others have already commented on the trendy decor and absolutely perfect location. The station and Shibuya centre are five minutes walk, and we walked to Harajuku in one direction and Daikanyama in the other. There are many small eating places around the hotel which is on the quieter side of Shibuya station. Access is so easy - catch the limousine bus to the Cerulean Hotel (easier with luggage and skis than the train). With your back to the Cerulean walk to your right, past the steps to the station, turn right , and the Granbell is in either the third or fourth street on your right - you will have walked past the Family Mart and will turn right up the hill at the four- way intersection opposite the donut shop! Hotel is set back a little on the left-hand side. These were the directions we needed as we asked several people only metres from the hotel and no-one knew, even with the address in Japanese! The blocks are small and the walk is about five minutes.We booked two twin rooms so we could be together (twin and doubles are on different floors). The twin rooms have ample room for suitcases and clothes. Our rooms were the only two at our end of the corridor and perfect for a family.We had no problem with building noise as the annex being built was well below floor nine. Previous reviewer commented on this and it could be a problem if you were at eye level with builders (although we tend to be out during construction hours).Before booking I emailed the hotel with several questions and received prompt, friendly, helpful replies in English.We would certainly stay at the Granbell again.

This hotel in Shibuya is such an amazingly great place to stay! The location was excellent, close to everything and an easy short walk from the station. Staff were extremely friendly and the room was impeccable. Everything was modern and clean, and although small, the single room was roomy enough to be comfortable. The lobby and corridors are very modern and cool, and all this for $AUS110 per night! I would totally recommend anyone to stay here, convenient, beautiful and helpful friendly staff. Also have complimentary internet access in rooms plus MTV to check out crazy Japanese music :)Also, if you have a suitcase, the overpass from the station to the Granbell on the Tokyo Plaza side of the road has a ramp up and down (easier than lugging case up stairs).

Stayed in the single room for 3 nights on Nov 2007.The room was rather small but sufficient for a single traveller. Able to open up my luggage on the floor to pack without much difficultes.Room is tastefully decorated. Felt like I was in a botique hotel :)Hotel is located near the busy Shibuya area. Less than 5 mins walk from Shibuya train station (one of the major train station). Very convienent as a base to get around.Hotel has a 24hrs bistro and beside it, there's a 24 hrs convinence store where you can pop by to buy drinks/snacks.For people who plan to bunk in with friends in a single room, please take note that the shower room is a total see through from the bed.Only downside is that they refuse to grant us FOC late check-out. But for the price I'd paid (JPY10,000 per night), I'm not complaining.

I stayed at the Granbell in early October after reading about this hotel as a great budget find in the LUXE guide. The Granbell is a modern botique hotel and it was the perfect home base for exploring Tokyo. I was traveling by myself and opted for one of the single rooms which was very stylish with pop art curtains and a lime green door. The room was small but very efficiently organized - a desk with flat screen TV, built in safe, computer hookup, etc.. a very modern bathroom and single platform bed. Just big enough for me but too small for two people. There are much larger rooms/studios available but they were a lot more expensive. On the last night a fashion shoot for a Japanese magazine was being shot in the bigger room accross the hall. The lobby has a fun 24 hour bar/restaurant called POP (Plate of Pie). And the staff was very friendly and helpful for printing maps and making reservations which is key in Tokyo. All this is about a 3 minute walk from Shibuya crossing (the busiest pedestrian intersection featured in Lost in Translation) and the Shibuya JR Train station. Granbell is the Bee's Knees and I'd highly recommend , specially for single travelers looking for style on a budget in a great location.

My boyfriend and I spent 4 wonderful nights at the Granbell hotel in Shibuya, Tokyo. With all the sights to see in Tokyo, we didn't spend much time in the hotel. The hotel's location made it an excellent home base for sightseeing. Just a few minutes from the hotel is Shibuya station, a major subway and train hub. The JR line goes direct from the airport to Shibuya. The hotel is tucked away in a quiet street, yet so close to the action of Shibuya. The location is perfect!We spent 2 days in a double room, left for an overnight trip to the mountains (the hotel was kind enough to store our luggage), then came back and spent another 2 days in a single room for two people. The double room was clean, modern, quiet, and well designed. It had a comfortable bed, gloriously powerful shower, and the obligatory Japanese "toilet from the future," as my boyfriend liked to call it.The single room (we booked late and couldn't get a double room for our second stay), was more what we expected from a Japanese hotel. Very small, but still well designed and comfortable. This room is more suited for a single person, as the name states. We found the room rates very resonable.Next time we visit Tokyo we will definitely be staying at the Granbell again. Our stay there was thoroughly enjoyable and we would recommend it without hesitation.

me and girlfriend spent 5 nights in april and can only recommend this hotel. quite a stylish place with a very helpfull frontdesk (including free sony vaio rental).very very good location for getting completly lost in the madness that is shibuya. plenty of food options available nearby, a 24 hour snackbar inside the granbell makes a good option for one, or two nightcaps. and of course the bathrooms are hightech ;)

My husband and I have just come back from a fabulous 3 night stay at the new Granbell Hotel located in Shibuya, Tokyo. We booked a standard double room (which was a very reasonable price) and found it to be a really funky, cool and comfortable place to stay. The staff were all very friendly and helpful (they lent us a laptop to take to our room to use the internet for free and made lots of bookings for us). The location is amazing as it's only a 3 minute walk to Shibuya station which connects you to many of the train lines to get around Tokyo. It is also only a 5 minute walk to the shops, restaurants and bars of Shibuya.Our room was a good size for Tokyo, ie not cramped and had a very nice shower and bath. The bed was a king size and was very comfortable and we didn't notice any noise during the night.If you are into cool, hip, boutique style hotels in a great location then I would definately recommend staying here. A hint for anyone who has not travelled to Tokyo before, if you are using taxis get your hotel to write down your destination in Japanese to give to the driver as most do not read / understand English.
